Mr Brown will work on land transport, road safety and maritime operations and will assist Mr Willis with maritime policy. Responsibilities within other portfolios remain unchanged.

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam Speaker, I inform the House that the Treasurer (Mr Keating) left on 21 September on Government business overseas. He will return to Australia on 13 October. In his absence the Minister for Employment, Education and Training, Mr Dawkins, is the Acting Treasurer. SPEECH.SPEAKER: Howard The Hon J.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam Speaker, I seek leave to make a short statement.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I welcome the confirmation by the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) of details that were already widely known in the community. I say to the Prime Minister and to the House that, rather than provide the House with details that are well known, he might have better used the time and allowed the Attorney-General (Mr Lionel Bowen) to explain to the Australian community how the Government justified wasting $46m on an ill-fated referendum campaign.
—Order! The Chair was under the impression that the Leader of the Opposition wished to make a similar statement to that of the Prime Minister.

—No. I sought leave to make a short statement in response to the statement made by the Prime Minister. I did not seek leave to make any other statement. With respect, the Chair was in error if that is what you thought that you gave me leave for.
—The Chair gave leave to the Leader of the Opposition to make a short statement on the same lines--

—No, you gave me leave to make a short statement. Let me simply repeat that the time that the Prime Minister took up would have been better employed with the Attorney-General justifying to the Australian public the waste of $46m on the referendum campaign and the Opposition looks forward with great interest to the performance of the Government's new front bench.
—The Leader of the Opposition will now resume his seat.
—On what basis?

—I raise a point of order, Madam Speaker. It is worth while your reflecting on the proceedings of the last little while. The Leader of the Opposition sought leave. You did not give leave; leave was given by the Parliament. You are the Speaker and you adjudicate in this place; you do not give leave. Secondly, the Leader of the Opposition was given leave to make a statement. It was not a statement on a specific issue. The House having given leave, you are not in a position where in any way you can require him to make any remarks other than those he chooses. Thirdly, I trust that in the course of Question Time today and on other occasions you will also intervene in answers by Ministers when they go beyond what we regard as reasonable. If you can intervene when leave is given to make a statement, you can intervene to require Ministers to terminate their answers when they go beyond a reasonable length.
—The Chair was under the impression, as I imagine the House was under the impression, that the Leader of the Opposition was intending to make the same type of statement as the Prime Minister.
—He did not say that.
—In that case the Chair was in error, but so also was the House in giving leave.
—I am quite sure that the House was under the impression that the Leader of the Opposition was going to make a similar statement to that of the Prime Minister.

—I wish to speak to the point of order raised by the Leader of the National Party. I remind you, Madam Speaker, of an earlier occasion when the Prime Minister made a similar statement and I sought and obtained leave to make comments on a variety of matters that did not include providing a list of the shadow Ministry. Your recollection of those events is in error.

—My question is directed to the Prime Minister. We acknowledge that it is proper that Mr Hayden as Governor-General designate should call on the Queen before he takes up office, but the Prime Minister will be only too well aware that over the past 5 1/2 years Mr Hayden, unlike previous Governors-General designate, as Australia's most travelled Foreign Minister has more than familiarised himself with the world in the course of his 40-plus arduous overseas trips. Will the Prime Minister now explain why the Australian taxpayer should pay for a 39-day world tour by Mr Hayden and others? Will he explain the reasons for Mr Hayden's itinerary and the special relevance of his visiting such places as Paris, Zurich and Spain or visiting New York yet again-a city he visited on a number of occasions at government expense? What, pray, is the cost of this grand tour to the Australian taxpayer?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hawke The Hon R.J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —All the arrangements that are being made in respect of the proposed visit by Mr Hayden are fully in accordance with precedents applying to former Governors-General designate. I will be more than happy to give a full answer to the question asked by the honourable member for North Sydney. Governors-General designate have traditionally travelled overseas prior to being sworn in. The Governor-General designate, as I think honourable members know, visits the Queen to discuss matters associated with the future performance of the functions of the Governor-General as Her Majesty's representative in Australia. A period overseas for Governors-General designate also provides a complete break from previous professional life before taking up the important--

ANSWER.PARA: Opposition members-Ha, ha!

TALK.START.PARA: —I can see that we are going to have another session of the giggles-the giggle, giggle, giggle-which has been no substitute for policy. If the giggle is the best the honourable member can do he is guaranteed to be with us in that position not much longer, which is unfortunate.

ANSWER.PARA: What has been done in the past is that an opportunity has been provided for the Governor-General designate to visit the Queen and to have a complete break from his previous professional life before taking up the important and demanding duties of Governor-General. In the visit that the Governor-General designate will undertake he will not necessarily-it is most unlikely-be meeting precisely the same sorts of political figures he met in his role as Foreign Minister.

Let me make clear how much in line with previous practice is what is being done by Mr Hayden. Sir Zelman Cowen, prior to his taking up the office and on his visit to meet the Queen, visited the United Kingdom, the Netherlands, the United States of America, China and Japan over a period of 46 days. Sir Ninian Stephen travelled to Yugoslavia, Italy-including Sicily-the United Kingdom, the United States and Canada over 40 days. The Commonwealth met all costs associated with the visits, other than the cost of Sir Zelman Cowen's visits to China and Japan where he was a guest of the Chinese and Japanese governments. All costs associated with Mr Hayden's visit will be met by my Department in accordance with those established precedents.

The proposed overseas visit by Mr Hayden is consistent with these precedents and, on that basis, was approved by the Secretary of my Department. Mr Hayden will be away for 39 days, leaving on 29 September and returning on 6 November. That 39 days compares with the 46 days in the case of Sir Zelman Cowen and 40 days in the case of Sir Ninian Stephen. An officer of my Department will accompany Mr Hayden. Sir Zelman Cowen travelled with a police escort and Sir Ninian Stephen was accompanied by his associate.

I conclude on the point I made during this answer earlier, that is, that the assumption that Bill Hayden will on this visit be seeing exactly the same people he saw and performing the same functions he performed as Foreign Minister is obviously erroneous. It is a stupid assumption made by a stupid collection of people who sit opposite.

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam Speaker, I take a point of order. The Prime Minister failed to answer the question in not telling us how much the trip would cost.

—Can the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy advise the House of the reaction to the Government's decisions on the new wheat marketing arrangements?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Kerin The Hon J.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the honourable member for Rankin for his question and acknowledge his very close interest on behalf of the wheat growers in his area. Honourable members will recall the somewhat fuzzy and fabricated fury of the Grains Council of Australia when I announced that the Government was proposing to commercialise fully the Australian Wheat Board and the domestic wheat market. There are all sorts of wild claims about potential losses to growers, when in fact growers will actually benefit in net terms. But as usual the unthinking National Party of Australia jumped straight in and supported all these ridiculous claims.

ANSWER.PARA: There are two certainties in this place. The first is that the National Party will always support the lowest common denominator, particularly if that denominator is concocted in Queensland where the National Party hates the Liberal Party. But members of the National Party have made a mistake. Contrary to the fabricated fury of the Grains Council, the only proper survey of genuine wheat farmers shows that 41 per cent of growers support deregulation and some 47 per cent support competition in feed wheat exports. The question facing the Government is why individual growers should be restricted in their marketing choice. The present restrictions in the domestic market just cannot be justified, so the Government will proceed with commercialising the Australian Wheat Board and the market. Growers will be free to choose, and they will choose the most efficient marketing, transport, storage and handling system. This will improve the efficiency of the system and so increase growers' net terms.

The other certainty in this place is that the Liberals will be confused. There is an old army joke about the confusion of officers; here it is the confusion of the Liberals. I refer first to the honourable member for Wannon-a sensible chap whose electorate will be a Liberal-National Party election battleground this coming Saturday. He persuaded his shadow Cabinet to take a sensible point of view, and in so doing rolled his fellow Victorian, the Deputy Leader of the National Party. The Leader of the Opposition was nowhere to be seen. He was leading from behind again. But the Western Australian Liberals disagreed. The honourable member for O'Connor has said in his electorate that as a parliamentarian he opposes deregulation but as a farmer he supports it. He is a real man of principle. The local Nationals over there then claimed, to quote them, that the acquired immune deficiency syndrome issue rated higher on his hit list of priorities than did representing his wheat grower constituents. This was too much for the honourable member for O'Connor. He can dish it out but he cannot take it. He capitulated completely to support the status quo, saying in the prestigious Wheatbelt Mercury:
It is time Mr Howard stopped worrying about his image and supported the Grains Council of Australia.

So there we have it. The Leader of the Opposition has been sitting there in silence worrying about his image; the Liberals are confused and the coalition is divided. This is the state of coalition harmony in this country, and that would be the result of an Opposition win in Victoria. While they have their battles we will get on with the business of running the country, and I am sure John Cain will get on with the business of running Victoria properly.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Prime Minister, and follows the previous question asked of him. I refer to the Prime Minister's answer in which he said, amongst other things, that Mr Hayden would be having a break-a break at taxpayers' expense. I assume, as Governor-General designate, he will be exchanging views with other heads of state. If that is the case, is it so, as the press reports, that he will be visiting Austria and having a break with Dr Waldheim?

—Has the Minister for Employment, Education and Training seen the report in today's Australian Financial Review which sets out the latest figures on manufacturing employment? Can the Minister advise the House whether these figures accord with developments elsewhere in the labour market?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Dawkins The Hon J.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think it is fair to say that the proudest boast of this Government, particularly as a Labor government, is the way it has transformed the labour market during the period it has been in office. The creation of a million jobs is just not a statistic. It means that a million people have been lifted out of poverty, and therefore hundreds and thousands of families throughout Australia have been lifted out of poverty, out of the social security system, and put back into the work force. Those people can earn a decent living and look after their families appropriately. We will go on and on acclaiming that this is the single greatest achievement of this Government, an achievement which is not over yet and which is continuing to build on our already impressive record. Employment has grown by 17.4 per cent since April 1983; unemployment has fallen from 10 per cent-that terrible legacy left to us by our opponents-to 7 per cent; more than half the jobs have been taken up by women; and, as impressive as anything, the unemployment rate for the teenage population has fallen from over 12 per cent to under 7 per cent. Whereas young people had the worst job outlook, their position is now better than that in the community as a whole.

ANSWER.PARA: The honourable member referred me to an article relating to manufacturing employment. This gives a stark comparison of the record of this Government and that of its predecessor. During the period 1976-83 manufacturing employment actually fell by an average rate of 1.6 per cent per year, whereas between 1983 and the present, over the last five years, it rose by 0.8 per cent every year. Indeed, in the last 12 months, as if that five-year period were not significant enough, manufacturing employment has risen by a staggering 4.2 per cent. This is all because this Government, through its macro-economic policy and the micro-economic adjustments which it is proceeding with, has achieved circumstances in which manufacturing has not been driven into the ground by a generally uncompetitive Australian economy, but rather is now able to hold its head up high and compete with the rest of the world.

I am sure the honourable member for Bendigo would like me to refer to his home State of Victoria where, compared with all the other States, there has been a greater rate of growth and there have been more jobs and more exports. Some 14,600 jobs have been created in the manufacturing sector of Victoria alone. These jobs do not just materialise, but are the result of investment decisions made by Australian business. In regard to private business in Victoria in the period 1983-88, the investment rate was double that for Australia as a whole. Although the annual rate of growth in manufacturing investment in Victoria was 2.3 per cent during the years before we came into office and before the Cain Government came into office, in the last five years there has been a massive 7.2 per cent per annum increase in the investment in manufacturing industry. Although we saw our opponents, the Liberal Party both in Victoria and nationally, devastate the manufacturing industry, we have been able to rescue it and give it a future, and its future is nowhere rosier than it is in Victoria.

TALK.START.PARA: —I address my question to the Acting Treasurer. Is it a fact that since this year's May statement, housing interest rates have increased by one per cent to 14.5 per cent? Is it a further fact that a one per cent rise in housing rates increases home loan repayments on, for example, a $50,000 mortgage by $40 a month? Is that equivalent to a tax increase of 6 per cent for the average income earner?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Dawkins The Hon J.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —Why anyone would take any notice of the projections of the Deputy Leader of the Opposition I simply do not know, and certainly one would not bestow any credibility whatever on any kind of financial equations that he might like to manufacture. I shall not speculate on the general direction of interest rates. Indeed, everybody knows that it is highly irresponsible to speculate about short term forecasts for interest rates. What I can say is that this Government has set the circumstances whereby there will be a general downward trend in interest rates. Let me tell honourable members about some of the underlying circumstances which have created that environment.

ANSWER.PARA: Opposition members interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —I would not have thought that the Leader of the Opposition would want to have his record on interest rates, or on anything else for that matter, ventilated in this House or in the nation. He has the shabbiest record of any person who has been in the position of Treasurer at any time. As far as this Government is concerned, as a result of bringing in a Budget which has within it a $5 1/2 billion surplus--

—Madam Speaker, I raise a point of order. The Minister is obviously out of his depth. In the question he was asked to advise whether interest rates historically had gone up. Could you ask him to address the relevant part of that question?
—The honourable member will resume his seat. The Minister is answering the question.

—It might come as a surprise to the Deputy Leader of the Opposition that interest rates are actually influenced by a very complex set of circumstances. Of course, there was a time when the Opposition liked to believe that the Australian economy could live insulated from the rest of the world. This Government made the very deliberate decision to ensure that the Australian economy was as exposed as possible to the rest of the world so that we could show how well we competed and we are showing just that. Interest rates are a very important indicator of how well we are achieving in comparison with the rest of the world.

ANSWER.PARA: Three major factors represent the Government's responsibility with regard to the interest rate environment. One is fiscal policy and the fact that, as a result of our overall Budget surplus, there will be no net borrowing by the public sector in this country. That must have an easing effect on interest rates. As well, we have declining inflation. Again, that should have a moderating effect on interest rates. The new deregulatory measures in the banking system will continue to exert downward pressure on bank loans. Of course, we do not pretend that those are the only factors which influence interest rates. There are, of course, the demands for funds by the private sector in Australia and interest rate levels in the world financial markets.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy Speaker, I raise a point of order with regard to relevance. Of course, the question related to the $40 increase in monthly household payments confronting all home owners. All we asked the Minister to do was to confirm whether people have to suffer that--
—Order! The honourable member has raised the question of relevance.
—Yes, and I ask you to ask him to tell the people of Australia whether they are suffering that or not.
—Order! The honourable member will resume his seat.
—It sounds more like his tax return.
—Order! The Minister shall continue his answer.
—I would be happy to send the honourable member for O'Connor an elementary textbook on first year economics. That might suit his purposes for the occasion.
—You failed everything at university. They had to send you to Roseworthy to get your diploma.
—At least I did not have to switch parties to get here.
—Your mother wouldn't let you.
—Order! If the honourable member for O'Connor continues to interject I shall name him.

—I do not intend to give any comfort to the Opposition in terms of its calculations. Members of the Opposition are the ones who are trying to play politics with regard to interest rates and the fortunes of Australian home owners. We will pursue the current policy stance, in relation to both fiscal policy and monetary policy, recognising that monetary policy, as the Treasurer says, must continue to play its vital balancing role in the overall economic strategy.

—Has the Minister for Trade Negotiations seen reports suggesting that Australia should join the European Economic Community? Can he inform the House how this would affect Australia's present trading relationships?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Duffy The Hon M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have seen the reports of statements by Mr John Elliott of Elders IXL Ltd who, amongst other things, is President of the Liberal Party of Australia. It is reported that he has expressed the view that Australia should apply for entry into the European Community. I think, leaving aside considerations of the merits or demerits of any future Australian membership of a trade or economic bloc, region or otherwise, the rules of the Treaty of Rome do not allow for any Australian application for membership. So that is one problem.
—Is it Liberal Party policy?

—No, it is not. The Prime Minister just asked me whether it was Liberal Party policy. It is a bit difficult to ascertain Liberal Party policy on trade. If the Prime Minister will bear with me I will deal with that. The point of real concern from Mr Elliott's point of view is that Article 237 of the Treaty of Rome, establishing the European Economic Community, states that any European state may apply to become a member of the Community. Of course, it may well be, having regard to Opposition statements on immigration recently, that those opposite are not too sure of which part of the world we live in. But I can assure those opposite that it is not intended that Australia should propose to any member state of the European Community that it should submit a proposal under the terms of the Treaty of Rome, which lays down the legal processes for treaty amendments, for the removal of the word `European'. The proposal is somewhat extraordinary.

ANSWER.PARA: Of course, Mr Elliott is at odds-the Prime Minister was interested in this-with other statements made on trade by members on the opposite side of the House. The former Prime Minister, Mr Malcolm Fraser, has recently suggested that Australia should concentrate its efforts on trading blocs in the Asian and Pacific regions and should not join the European Community. Mr Malcolm Fraser's view has been echoed by the honourable member for North Sydney and also the honourable member for Mayo. So we do have some agreement. We then had the Leader of the National Party of Australia commenting on my suggestion that we should examine a Pacific rim trade group. He agreed that there was potential in that but, in fairness, he also suggested that we should not blow out the candle on the Uruguay Round. It is good to have the opportunity to assure the right honourable member for New England that this Government has no intention of doing that. In fact, tomorrow--

TALK.START.PARA: —It only needs a puff.

—The right honourable member had better make up his mind. He now says that it only needs a puff to blow it out. I thought he was a strong supporter and I am disappointed that he now thinks it just needs a puff to blow it out. It is very difficult to know where any Opposition member stands on this matter. Tomorrow I will be leaving for Pakistan to attend the informal Trade Ministers Conference to discuss the Uruguay Round.
—It will be a fantastic visit.

—The Deputy Leader of the Opposition interjects. I can assure him that it is an extremely important meeting and it involves a considerable sacrifice because on the two weekends I will be away the Turnbull Stakes and the Caulfield Guineas will be run in Australia and I will miss the company of the Deputy Leader of the Opposition at both those meetings. The Pakistan meeting will be the first of a series of meetings leading to the mid-term review in Montreal and the importance of that we all know.

ANSWER.PARA: I think it is worth stating that Australia has been at the forefront in the Uruguay Round. The efforts of my predecessor in the portfolio, Minister Dawkins, both through the formation and continuation of the Cairns Group and in our own right, will be maintained right through the four years of this round. The Government's trade policy stands in stark contrast to that of those opposite.

TALK.START.PARA: —Wind it up. He has had plenty of time.

—I think if I need any advice as to when I should wind it up, it will come from elsewhere, rather than from the honourable member. When a trade policy is produced by the Liberal and National parties-and that we eagerly await-we think it will be the same mishmash as other policies. In closing, I think it is worth noting their rural policy, which somehow leaked. The Australian editorial section of 20 September says:

ANSWER.PARA: It is high time the Federal Coalition got its act together and came up with a rural policy with some genuine vision, purpose and specific direction instead of its traditional pile of sententious waffle.

—Can the Minister for Social Security tell the House the meaning of the latest unemployment beneficiary figures in Victoria?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Howe The Hon B.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —One of the achievements that the Government has referred to has been the level of the job creation that has occurred during the period that we have been in government. We do not normally draw attention to the statistics with respect to unemployment benefit, so we have not drawn as much attention as we might to the falls that have occurred in the number of unemployment beneficiaries.
—There is a 90 per cent increase in regional Victoria.

—Incidentally, Victoria, as the right honourable member for New England I am sure would be interested to know, has had the fastest fall in unemployment and has contributed significantly to the nationwide drop of 26.3 per cent in the number of people receiving unemployment benefit during the past five years. The figures show that the number of unemployment beneficiaries fell nationally by 163,336, that is from a peak of 622,000 in August 1983 to 458,767 last month. Victoria has contributed one-third of the nationwide reduction in unemployment benefit numbers. This is of course a magnificent achievement for a State with 26 per cent of the nation's labour force.

The fact is that the claims of the Deputy Leader of the Opposition are, as he well knows, totally without foundation. Statistic after statistic, piece of evidence after piece of evidence that one turns to simply destroys and demolishes the arguments of the Deputy Leader of the Opposition. It was all about the fact that poor old Jeff Kennett got on the phone-presumably a more secure phone than they used on their last notorious conversation-and said, `For heaven's sake, Andrew, you are, after all, the Opposition spokesman on the economy'. Very few people around Australia know that but Jeff Kennett knows it. He said to the Deputy Leader, `For Heaven's sake, get on your hind legs in the House and try to drum up a bit of drama about the Victorian debt burden'. So the Deputy Leader of the Opposition said, `Yes, Jeff, I will do that. There is not a scintilla of evidence on which to base that claim, but nevertheless for you, Jeff, my mate, I will do that'. The Cain Government has committed itself to ensuring that debt continues to fall as a share of the non-farm State economy through the term for which it will be elected on Saturday. This is a phoney argument, just as phoney as the Opposition's reshuffle-induced euphoria-one that Opposition members alone can understand-nevertheless there are some very substantial reasons why the people of Victoria will disregard the advice of the Deputy Leader of the Opposition and once again turn to the Australian Labor Party and John Cain to see them through the next four years at least.

The reason for that was referred to a couple of times earlier today-that is, in Victoria there are more jobs, more growth, more opportunities for people, more prosperity and more exports than in any other State. TALK.START.PARA: —The Treasurer (Mr Keating) says that this Budget is `the one that brings home the bacon'. I wonder what he really means by that. I suspect he wants us to believe that this Budget pulls it all together, with restored balance in the economy, continuing strong growth and the debt being rolled back. Bluntly, that is not the reality. Let us be clear about some of the things the Treasurer does not and cannot mean. Certainly the Budget does not give any relief from the terrible weight of income taxation on the average Australian. That point has been hammered by previous Opposition speakers, but it is some three weeks since we debated this matter so it bears repeating: there is no relief from the terrible weight of income taxation on the average Australian. There is a small measure of relief via the lower tax on beer and a few other lower indirect taxes. But income taxes in total increased by 10 per cent last year and they are now projected to increase by 14 per cent this year-that is, by $5.7 billion-as, with the passing of time, the so-called bracket creep bites deeper and deeper. Note that that total, $5.7 billion, happens to be only slightly greater than the Budget surplus of $5.5 billion trumpeted forth with great boasting and thumping of the chest by the Treasurer, most recently before the International Monetary Fund in West Berlin in the past few days.

SPEECH.PARA: Thus, as one commentator put it, that is a surplus in the Budget `ripped out of the hides of ordinary Australians'. We can bet that statement is bang on. So I say this: At a time when the real incomes of ordinary Australians have fallen so under this Labor Government-I am referring to the goods and services one's wages will buy at the supermarket or the fruit market-and when Australians on low to average incomes are suffering the biggest falls, there is to be a further whacking increase in people's income taxes. It is immoral that ordinary Australians-we are not talking about rich people here-are forced to pay and go on paying 40c tax in the dollar for every extra dollar of income they earn, and so their overall tax rate increases. There is no bacon there; no way.

What it all amounts to is this: by 1 July next year, when there is some prospect that some bacon in the form of tax cuts will be delivered, the average wage and salary earner would need $56 a week to restore his real disposable income to the level of March 1983, when Labor came to power. I say again, $56 a week; that is the measure of how people are being thrashed by this highest taxing government in Australia's post-war history. The Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard) put it correctly when he said that under Labor `hard work in Australia is rewarded by higher taxes'. That is a great way to run a country. In addition, the way this Budget and overall policy are shaped, to higher taxes will be added higher interest rates.

That brings me to the other important way in which this Budget fails to bring home the real, the essential, `bacon' that is, it does not promise any significant contribution to getting this country out of the fundamental economic predicament of its vast balance of payments deficit and frightening overseas debt. Make no mistake, we are in this situation largely as a result of the economic policies of the Hawke-Keating Government. My colleague the honourable member for Wentworth (Dr Hewson) set that out in his speech earlier in this debate. The situation was exacerbated, it is true, by the decline in the terms of trade after 1985 but, and I underline this, all of that fall in the terms of trade has now been recovered.

Australia's situation of a massive balance of payments deficit and an ever-increasing overseas debt is a very serious one. It makes us very dependent on large scale borrowings from foreigners. That has been facilitated in recent years by all the money sloshing around the world economy. But we are still very vulnerable.

It is a situation which the Treasurer has on a number of occasions in the past-though not this time, with his economic zeal having been so blunted by his aspirations to the Lodge-described as being `unsustainable'. That is correct. Last year the balance of payments deficit-that is, what we are spending overseas in excess of what we are earning, and we may use the analogy of a person spending $450 a week when he is earning only $400-came in at $11.9 billion, or a billion dollars per calendar month. The July figure was $1.7 billion, but it is around $1 billion on average. That means that the country is going an extra $30m into hock every day.

Some have said-my friend the honourable member for Herbert (Mr Lindsay), amongst others, earlier in this debate-`But we are reducing our overseas debt', and much was made in the news this very morning of the Treasurer repaying or retiring $800m of Commonwealth debt. That is less than one month's worth-a billion dollars of our profligate new borrowing. Who says that our overseas indebtedness is falling? That is an illusion which the Treasurer would carefully foster-falsely-like other illusions and distortions conveyed by this Treasurer and the thrust of this Budget.

It is absolutely obvious that somewhere, somehow, someone has to borrow when one is running the economy so as to go $30m extra into hock, as I said, every day. In those circumstances, if the Government retires a bit of its debt, that does not change the overall situation-but it sure fosters the illusion of reducing the nation's indebtedness. The truth is that unless the Government accepts its overall responsibility-and it is the Government's responsibility-to run the economic affairs of the country so that the country lives within its income and does not chalk up that $30m extra every day, the Government is not facing up to its responsibilities and is putting us very much at risk. As I have said, someone, somewhere has to do the borrowing. Thus, we do find that the gross overseas debt went up last year by $10 billion, to $115 billion as at 30 June last; and the net debt went up by $7 billion, to nearly $90 billion. They are Reserve Bank of Australia figures-if anyone has any doubt-and there is no argument about them. So the debt relentlessly increases, and the carefully crafted illusion that our vast overseas debt is being cut is just that-phoney, false, an illusion.

What I am saying is that the key `bacon' that the Treasurer is not bringing home is a significant, a sufficient, a more certain contribution to the correction of the continual substantial deficit in the balance of payments which, as the Reserve Bank in its annual report rightly stresses:
. . . is central to Australia's economic strategy . . . to securing our economic future.
What that calls for, as the Reserve bank report says, is, first:
sustained improvement in the competitiveness of our industries-
which is threatened by too rapid wage increases and makes a tax cut now imperative. Secondly, it calls for a:
broader productive base . . . to complement resource export industries-
and involving:
the progressive transfer of resources into production for export and for import replacement.

A positive contribution is made to that when export volumes increase more than import volumes. But in the year just passed the reverse happened: import volumes increased faster than exports. And for crying out loud, the same result is forecast in the Treasurer's own Budget Papers for next year.

Where the Government has really let the long term future of the country down is in not reducing government spending more, which is the most direct way, under the Government's control, of making the economic room for the necessary additional investment and export and import replacement production. I know that the Treasurer, in his typically excessive, derogatory, plain wrong way, has said:
. . . parroted calls in future for further savage cuts in public spending should be seen for what they are; mindless shrieks by ideologues against the legitimate spending functions of government.
In response to that, I would ask: What about his colleague Senator Walsh's `two hundred bloody programs'-I might say that the `French' is the Senator's and these are his words-
that cannot be justified on social justice, equity, or economic efficiency grounds
and therefore should be cut?

TALK.START.PARA: —He is right.

—Yes, indeed; he is right. Is Senator Walsh a mindless ideologue? I conclude by saying that with his characteristic abuse, half-truths and bluster the Treasurer may win the political argument for a day, for a month or for a bit longer; but, in his continuing drive for the Lodge and his need to win friends and influence people and his colleagues, in this Budget he has let the country down very badly indeed.

SPEECH.PARA: In summary, it is a bland, soft Budget, despite its trumpeted surplus of $5 billion. There is, first, the massive tax hike governed above everything else by the political imperative of no tax cut until just before the next election. Secondly, there is the fact of no tax cuts now, thus endangering the essential wage-salary moderation. Thirdly, the pace of the country's adjustment to its massive external deficit and overseas debt problem is slowed to a virtual standstill. It is a soft Budget that really lets this country down.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have pleasure in supporting the Appropriation Bills, as I have done every year since my election to this House in 1983. I have to say that, of all the May statements and the Budgets that this Government has released in each year since that time, I think that in its fundamental characteristics this is the best Budget that this Federal Labor Government has been able to produce. I say that for a range of reasons, but I refer particularly to the principal characteristics of this Budget.

SPEECH.PARA: There are three basic, outstanding characteristics in this Budget. The first is that it returns a surplus to the Government in excess of $5 billion. To put that in context, that compares with an inherited deficit that we received in prospect on taking government in March 1983 from the irresponsible government at the time, with its Treasurer John Howard, of $9.6 billion. That was the deficit in prospect that we inherited. We have turned that around after 5 1/2 difficult years. I know that they have been difficult years also for the Australian people, and we appreciate their support in that turnaround of the Australian economy. We have thus seen $9.6 billion in the red turned around to $5.5 billion in the black-a net turnaround of more than $15 billion. It has been financed primarily by expenditure cuts. That is the first outstanding feature of this Budget.

The second is that the private sector investment figures on which it is based forecast a 12 per cent real increase in investment in the Australian economy in this financial year, 1988-89. Obviously, investment is crucial to Australia's ability to improve its competitiveness, to put exports at a world price on to international markets, and to repay some of the debt that has accrued over many decades because of the imbalance in our exports and imports. Investment is crucial to make us more competitive, to get out into the export market. In this Budget the magic figure is a 12 per cent anticipated real increase in investment.

The third characteristic goes to the issue of debt, of which we have heard a lot of debate-much of it inaccurate-in this House today. The net public sector borrowing requirement in this Budget is zero-nil. To many people and to many members of this House, particularly Opposition members, `the public sector borrowing requirement' is a long expression; but what does it mean when one says that it is zero? It means that this year the whole government sector of Australia will not be borrowing one new cent or dollar to finance any of its programs. To put that in context, let me emphasise that in five years-in other words, since the time we took government in 1983-government borrowing has been reduced from $20 billion to zero. It is another dramatic turnaround.

The previous speaker, the honourable member for Berowra (Dr Harry Edwards), talked about debt. We agree with some of what he said. We agree that for this country debt is a problem. We agree that continuing unfunded current account deficits are a problem and that is why, in the 5 1/2 years since we have been the Federal Government, we have taken proper, responsible action and appropriate measures to deal with that current account problem. We see in this Budget that those measures have been effective. We can argue about the pace of adjustment, but it is the view of this Government that the decisions we have taken in a budgetary context, a fiscal context and in a labour market context have been rapid enough to improve Australia's current account position and, at the same time, have been sustainable domestically; in other words, the Australian people have been prepared to accept the rate of change which has occurred. When one looks at those three key statistics, such as the surplus, one will see that there is a $5 1/2 billion surplus in this Budget. We think that that is appropriate for Australia's needs. The Budget forecasts a 12 per cent real rise in private sector investment. We think that that is ideal for Australia at present. The third characteristic is that the public sector borrowing requirement is nil. It means that we are borrowing no new money and, indeed, during this financial year the Federal Government has been repaying debt.

I want also to touch on the question of outlays because it has been suggested in the debate today by the Opposition-of course, a Victorian election is to be held next Saturday, on 1 October; I will come to that in a moment-that this is a high taxing Government and that the surplus of $5 1/2 billion in this Budget has been achieved by slugging people in the hip pocket. It is not true to say that, and responsible Opposition members know that it is not true to say that. Outlays in this Budget as a proportion of gross domestic product (GDP) are 25 1/2 per cent. Four years ago they were 30 per cent. That means that we have cut government spending, government outlays, by 4 1/2 percentage points of GDP. That is an enormous cut which has been achieved over four years. Next year, just on the basis of these Budget figures, outlays will be 24 1/2 per cent of GDP. The honourable member for Berowra, who is in the chamber at the moment, knows that those figures are true: four years ago outlays represented 30 per cent of GDP, this year they represent 25 1/2 per cent of GDP and next year they will represent 24 1/2 per cent of GDP. He knows that when previous conservative governments were in office they could not match that sort of record when Australia needed that sort of record to get itself out of economic trouble. This Labor Government has taken responsible action, at the same time preserving our social justice commitments to those most in need in the community. We have cut spending from 30 per cent of GDP to 25 1/2 per cent this year, and 24 1/2 per cent next year.

One might ask: How does that stack up against the rest of the world? As the Treasurer (Mr Keating) would say, `Put that in the big picture'. To put that in the big picture, it means that Australia has an achievement which is unmatched by any of the other 22 member countries of the Organisation for Economic Cooperation and Development (OECD). That puts the matter in its context. For three years in Australia we have been reducing real outlays because economic circumstances demanded it. We have done that with the support of the Australian people, who have acknowledged the need to cut spending. Sometimes that hurts people, but they have supported us in that regard because it has been essential for Australia's long term good. We have done it, and no other country in the OECD could match that achievement. It is an achievement which is unmatched anywhere in the world. It means that after 5 1/2 years of Federal Labor Government we have a smaller but better public sector.

As I said earlier, the question of debt has been raised a number of times in this debate. I guess it has been raised in the context of the Victorian election to be held this Saturday. I suppose that if I were an Opposition member, I would be grasping at straws, or grasping fairly desperately at issues with which to try to run during this last week. Certainly, at this stage of the poll, the Victorian Cain Government is a long way ahead of Mr Kennett. That is not surprising when one thinks of the performance of the Cain Government over more than six years and contrasts that style and performance with that of Mr Kennett. I suppose it is a laughable comparison.

The Opposition has talked about debt because it has not had much else to talk about. I just want to make a few points about debt in Victoria. This year the Victorian debt gross domestic product ratio is about 28 per cent. One might say that that sounds pretty high, but what does it mean? It is the same level as it was seven years ago in 1981-82 when the Cain Government won office-or, to put it another way, in the last full year of the Hamer-Thompson Government. It is worth comparing it to that of the alleged old sage of the Liberal Party, Sir Henry Bolte, because when he was Premier of Victoria in the 1970s, State debt reached a staggering 44 per cent of Victorian GDP.

When the Deputy Leader of the Opposi- tion, the honourable member for Kooyong (Mr Peacock), comes into this place to try to support his mate in Victoria, Jeff Kennett-and that is all he is doing, trying to support a mate-and says that debt under the Cain Government in Victoria is high, people ought to put that in its proper context. It is not high. Indeed, the Victorian economy is better equipped than any other economy in Australia to repay that debt. What is more, it has been borrowing to put money into productive enterprise which will earn Victoria more jobs, more investment and more export income. I repeat that comparison. In the 1970s, under dear old Sir Henry Bolte, the perfect Premier in far right Liberal eyes, State debt was 44 per cent of GDP. Today it is less than 30 per cent. So the Cain Government and Treasurer Jolly have been reducing that level of debt every year to get it to a responsible level. I am told that by 1990-91 State debt as a share of GDP will fall to 25 per cent, which will be the lowest level, not in a decade, two decades or since Bolte, but the lowest level this century, in 90 years, and that is an outstanding performance.

The last thing I want to say about debt in Victoria is that public sector borrowing requirements have been reduced in every year of the Cain Labor Government. In six very good years of government those borrowing levels have fallen in real terms. Even if members of the Opposition argue, for whatever reason, that debt in Victoria is too high, the fact is that it has been falling each year in which the Labor Government has been in office. I think that probably says something about the conservative governments which preceded us.

The next point I want to make is in response to remarks about taxation. It has been said that taxation in Victoria is high. Again, that is simply not true. I suppose it makes interesting headlines and small talk in this Parliament in the lead-up to the State election on Saturday. There is an abundance of evidence to show that it is simply not true. I do not refer to State statistics, as the Minister for Land Transport and Shipping Support (Mr Robert Brown) knows. I refer to impartially collected statistics by organisations like the Australian Bureau of Statistics which show that Victoria is certainly not the highest taxing State and, indeed, since 1982-83, the year in which the Australian Labor Party won office, Victoria's growth in tax has been the lowest of all of the States.

—My dear friend over there should tell us about immigration. He is pretty hot on that but the trouble is that he runs for cover as soon as he is asked to speak the truth. The real trouble with this Budget, as we all know, is that the Treasurer has foreshadowed that inflation is to increase by only 4.5 per cent over the course of the next 12 months. We know that the annual rate as measured by the consumer price index (CPI) was 7.1 per cent at the end of June 1988-twice the average of 3.6 per cent for the Organisation for Economic Cooperation and Development (OECD). We know that the implicit price deflator for gross non-farm product was 7 per cent, up from 6 per cent in the financial year 1984-85. Yet the Budget forecasts a 4.5 per cent increase in the CPI this year. We even saw Bill Kelty from the Australian Council of Trade Unions telling the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission that it was not possible for that 4.5 per cent to be reached this year. We also know that the projected fall is based on a beer fiddle on indirect taxes which is going to account for 0.5 per cent and on the assumption that the rise in the exchange rate for the first half of 1988 will be sustained-we have seen what has happened to that-with the remainder presumably contingent on something like cheaper fresh vegetable prices. Each one of those factors, I would contend, is questionable.

SPEECH.PARA: As far as the maintenance of the exchange rate is concerned, we know that there has been a significant easing in the value of the Australian dollar over the course of the last few weeks. We know that a major part of many household budgets is the monthly mortgage repayment. Housing interest rates have gone up from 13 1/2 per cent to 14 1/2 per cent. Prime lending rates are now 15 1/2 per cent. They affect the small business and the farmers that the National Party represents. These increases will inevitably raise the CPI. Even the price of fresh food has not fallen since 30 June 1988. This month the Government's Prices Surveillance Authority-and I see that the honourable member for Canning (Mr Gear), the chairman of the Government committee on the subject, is here today-stated that vegetable, fruit, meat and tinned fish prices are set to rise even higher. Yet this is one area on which the Government is relying when it says that the CPI figure this year will be 4.5 per cent. Indeed, I would say that the minimal assessment of inflation for this year should be around 6 per cent, and I would not be at all surprised if the figure were higher.

We have had no tax concessions passed on. We have a CPI figure that is significantly higher than the Government's assessment. We have an interest rate level which we all accept is going higher, even though the Acting Treasurer does not seem to know what it is about, and we have people in Victoria still pretending that their State is managed properly. The reality is that State governments further aggravate the whole problem. Inflation is further augmented by the fact that there are State charges and State taxes that significantly affect even the living standards of people such as honourable members opposite.

One thing that really worries us on this side of the House is that the Labor Party has not understood that the July $1.7 billion current account deficit reflects one of the real problems we have in the Australian economy.

TALK.START.PARA: —Where are the August figures?

—We know the August figures, as my colleague has said, are not out. At the very least we expect them to be between $1.2 billion and $1.5 billion. No serious analyst can really argue the proposition that the Budget current account forecast is accurate. We all know that the forecast for the current account deficit is based on exports-essentially rural products and minerals-maintaining their value. Under this Government the pace of adjustment has been slowed down. The pace of adjustment has not been helped by such dramatic changes as those that were imposed through the export market development grants scheme. That scheme was supposed to run for five years. The Government has pruned it halfway through, thereby further delaying and putting into doubt the pace of adjustment that is necessary to encourage Australian exports in other than our traditional commodities and in the minerals sector. We know that wool prices are 20 per cent lower today than they were at the top of the market last year. Recently we have seen significant falls in the gold price. Indeed, at the moment there seems to be some expectation among analysts that gold might plateau at the relative low price of about $US375. We also know that there has been generally some doubt with respect to other metal prices. With respect to aluminium, for example, we are told by international analysts that there is a narrowing gap between supply and demand and that demand is also likely to ease. With so many of our major commodities thecurrent account has in fact improved--
—What would you do about it?

—We would not rely on them to the degree that the Government has, but we would encourage them as a balanced part of the Australian economy. The major failure of the Government's Budget is that the Government is trying to pretend that we are no longer dependent on those commodities. We on this side acknowledge that we are dependent on them and we would not pull away from them money to provide roads, we would not add to the taxation burden of our commodity producers, and we would not remove from those in the rural sector the range of assistance schemes such as income equalisation deposits (IEDs) which should be available this year. In fact, the Government should allow farmers, when there are good seasons and a lift in prices, to put away money so that in a time of drought they do not approach it asking for help. The point is that the Australian Labor Party does not even understand what IEDs are about. There needs to be a balance between the assistance provided with respect to traditional exports and those that we see as necessary in the service and manufacturing industries which, of course, have a role. The Government had a scheme with respect to export market development grants, but it pulled the rug out from under it. Indeed, there is no doubt that what the Government has done is to look at a current account scene which I suspect will be significantly worse than it appears because of the Government's actions.

SPEECH.PARA: Let us look at imports. In 1986-87 the volume of imports declined by 3.2 per cent. We saw in the July figures a significant increase in imports. We suggest that that is because consumption is running at a point which will not encourage any improvement in the current account deficit at the end of the year. So statistically we find that the Government is not encouraging traditional exports-indeed, it is prejudicing their production and it is not helping with diversification. We have an increase in imports that will not help significantly. There is no increase in investment. The money coming into Australia is not for new plant and machinery; it is essentially there for consumer goods. The result of all that is to prejudice further Australia's competitiveness and to make the long term future even worse.

Looking at the terms of trade, the Budget continues the Government's record of placing inordinate stress on the commodity or net barter terms of trade. We are concerned that even the Budget focus on the commodity terms of trade is open to serious question. The Government's forecast in 1987 that there would be a 2 per cent rise in commodity trade was bettered-not because of Government action but because of an upturn in world commodity prices. Honourable members opposite will recall that the price was 9.4 per cent better over the course of that year than the Budget forecast of 2 per cent. That occurred not because of what the Government did but simply because world market conditions changed.
It is worth while remembering the sober advice of the Reserve Bank of Australia in its annual report released on 23 August this year where it said:
While the rise in commodity prices is very welcome, from Australia's viewpoint it cannot be taken for granted that the levels of mid-1988 will continue for long.

However, it is on that level that the whole of the Australian Budget surplus and the whole of the Australian economy are based. With respect to external debt, I refer to the fact that the Treasurer is overseas and, with great fanfare, has announced the repayment of a mere $800m in debt. The reality is that, as far as our surplus is concerned, of course he should be repaying debt. However, we must understand that the value of the Australian dollar affects the level of debt, and that the level of debt under Labor is likely to be somewhere about $11 billion up on the net debt at the end of this financial year on what it was at the beginning of this financial year simply because of the adverse balance of payments.

We have all sorts of problems and concerns with respect to the Budget itself. There is no doubt that the cut of 9 per cent in government support for the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation, which comes on top of a total reduction of 23 per cent over the previous four Budgets, will certainly affect the agricultural sector and will certainly affect our ability to produce commodities in the future. The Government has not addressed the problem of government regulation and excessive charges which, according to the Business Council of Australia, add at least $2 billion per annum to the nation's freight bill. The Government has cut funds for roads by 6.4 per cent in 1988-89, which makes the total real funding cut for roads under Labor since 1983-84 about 25 per cent. The Government has also cut assistance for isolated children by 16 per cent, thus reducing by nearly 24 per cent-it affects nearly 4,500 Australian children-the number of students being assisted under the assistance for isolated children scheme.

There is no doubt that, when one looks at the Budget, one can see that its strategies have failed in those three areas that I have attempted to identify-the external debt, the terms of trade and the current account deficit. We face real difficulties in those areas, along with the failure to pass on personal income tax cuts. If one asked average Australian workers today whether they were better off after the succession of Keating Budgets than they were in 1983, whether Australia is restructuring its economy rapidly enough to meet the increasingly harsh challenges of success in the world economy, and whether they should be paying tax at the present crippling tax rates, the answer would be no. This Government's Budget has failed 5 1/2 weeks after its delivery, and it has failed because the Government has not addressed the fundamental concerns that confront ordinary children, ordinary taxpayers and the ordinary men and women of Australia. The Government is remote. It is out of touch with the Australians and it is certainly out of touch with rural Australians wherever they might live and work.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gear Mr G.

TALK.START.PARA: —That contribution from the Leader of the National Party of Australia (Mr Sinclair) epitomises what is wrong with the Opposition today. It was a tired old speech given by a tired old leader who not only does not have a future but certainly does not have a past. I will go through some of the things that he said and remind him of his record and the record of this Government when comparisons are made. The Leader of the National Party spoke about external debt. One might ask which government put this country on the road to our present external debt. I would ask the Leader of the National Party to go back to 1982-83 when, as a percentage of gross domestic product (GDP), the debt in this country was the highest it has ever been. Certainly one of the most significant factors contributing to our external debt is the fact that we do not have a manufacturing base in this country. Virtually everything that we buy-all our consumer goods-is imported from overseas. If one goes back through history, the reason for that is the protectionist policies of the Liberal and National parties during the 1950s and 1960s. Those parties propped up inefficient industries in this country to a point where ultimately they collapsed in the late 1970s and early 1980s. We are starting the long haul towards getting our manufacturing industries back to prosperity. That will cut our external debt.

SPEECH.PARA: We are going through some of the tough times that have resulted from the policies of the past given to us by men of the past like the Leader of the National Party, who just spoke. He spoke about tax cuts. What a joke from the Leader of the National Party who was a Cabinet member in the previous Government. I remind the Leader that when that Government snatched office in 1975 the top tax rate was 60c in the dollar; and, when that Government was kicked out of office in 1983, the top tax rate was still 60c in the dollar. The present Government has been in office for 5 1/2 years and the top tax rate is now 49c in the dollar. In addition, the 46c rate which he was happy to keep for seven years is now down to 40c in the dollar. More importantly, when we think about people on low incomes, the bottom rate of 30c under his Government has dropped down to 24c.

When he was a member of the previous Government, the Leader of the National Party was content to retain those high tax rates, but this Government has cut those tax rates and next year it will cut them again. So when one looks at the performance of this Government compared with the rhetoric of members opposite, we have delivered whereas the previous Government never did. The Leader of the National Party also talked about the present Treasurer (Mr Keating) being the highest taxing Treasurer. It really is a cheap throwaway line to say that we have the highest taxing Treasurer. One can say that every year but, of course, in any expanding economy there will be more taxes. I take the Leader of the National Party and other members opposite back to 1982-83 when we had a shrinking economy. One had a right to complain if more taxes were being collected then, but to complain about more taxes in an expanding economy seems to me to be the cheapest throwaway line of all.

In terms of taxes collected, Australia is a low taxing country. In fact, of the 23 Organisation for Economic Cooperation and Development (OECD) countries we are the eighteenth lowest. There are 17 countries in the OECD which collect more taxes than does Australia. When I was in Melbourne last week I saw a sign on the side of the road for the Opposition Leader, Mr Kennett, which said something like, `taxes down, living standards up'. One has to conceptualise what Mr Kennett is trying to do in Victoria. It is exactly what the Liberals are trying to do here. The Liberals are trying to tell the Australian people that they can have lower taxes and a higher standard of living.

I will get back to the point I made before: the lowest taxing country in the OECD is Turkey. If members of the Opposition want Turkey's tax rates they will get Turkey's education, they will get Turkey's health provisions, and they will get Turkey's social security provisions. But they should not come in here and say we can have lower taxes and a higher standard of living because it is just not on. The people of Australia know that. The people of Victoria know that. Next week I am sure that the grab for the hip pocket, the line that the Leader of the Opposition in Victoria is going on with, will be exposed for what it is-a fraud. The Liberal Party and the National Party have always treated the electorate as mugs. They always seem to think that they can say to them, `You will pay less tax but you will get more for it'. The fact is that that cannot be done. My little bloke, who is only 11, would not believe that, yet the Liberal Party time and time again says, `Let's lower taxes'. If the Liberals want Turkish tax rates they should be honest enough to tell the people that they will get Turkish social security provisions and all that goes with that.

The Leader of the National Party also talked about inflation. When he was kicked out of office, the inflation rate stood at 11.7 per cent. When he got into office it was much the same. For those of us with a memory, back in 1975 that was the Opposition's No. 1 priority: `Let's get rid of inflation; let's cut inflation'. It had seven years in which to do it but it failed. By the standard it set itself, it failed. When the Opposition was kicked out, inflation was higher than it was when the Opposition got into office. This year it is down to 7.1 per cent-a figure the Opposition never approached in government. The projection for this year is about 4 1/2 per cent, and this Government will achieve that.

The Leader of the National Party also talked about the current account deficit. When we assumed office it was minus 4 per cent. The Government of which he was a member was actually spending 4 per cent more, expressed as a percentage of GDP, than it was collecting in taxes. We have turned that around in five years to a surplus of 1.7 per cent this year. That is what this Government has done; yet the Leader of the National Party has the gall to talk about the current account deficit. It does not matter which measure-the economic or social measure-is chosen to compare this Government with the previous one, we come out a mile ahead.

We go to the reasons why we can give tax cuts. One of the main reasons is that we repaired the taxation system. For example, this year the capital gains tax will bring directly into the tax coffers $100m which was never collected before. We remember, when we gave notice that we would not allow entertainment deductions, the show stacked on by the Opposition. One has to ask who was taking advantage of those entertainment deductions. It certainly was not the worker. The worker always took his lunch to work-the vegemite sandwiches in a brown paper bag.

TALK.START.PARA: —And paid for their lunches.

—And, as the Minister rightly points out, cross-subsidised those people who were having lunches in restaurants and booking them up to the taxpayer. One would think that fairness would dictate that it would be valuable to put equity back into the taxation system, but the Opposition opposed the proposition all the way down the line. I am glad to say that, as a result of that and other measures, the tax net has been closed substantially and we are collecting more taxes. We do not make any apologies for that.

SPEECH.PARA: Substantiation is another area. We will always remember how the Opposition fought the introduction of the fringe benefits tax all the way down the line. On the fringe benefits tax it said, `Axe the tax'. The opponents of the fringe benefits tax did not have to look far in this chamber to find friends. It was the Liberal and National parties that opposed the introduction of the fringe benefits tax, whereby a section of this community, instead of taking all its income in cash, as do pay as you earn taxpayers, and paying all of the tax on that cash income, were able to manipulate their income so that they received a portion of it in cash which was taxed and a significant amount of it in fringe benefits which were not taxed. That tax this year will bring in $1,000m. That is $1,000m which was never collected before but which should have been.

This Government has introduced legislation for a tax file number. It will be very interesting to find out what the Opposition's stand is on the tax file number. We cannot find out what its position is at the moment. It is sitting on the fence. We know what the Australian Democrats are saying. They will oppose it for some reason which escapes me. It seems to me that the Democrats are opposed to every measure to raise taxes but they are for every measure to spend them. It seems that the Liberal and National parties are going the same way. Let me get back to the workers in the street. They are paying less tax now as a percentage of their income than they were before, and they will be paying less next year. The reason for that is the repairs we have made to the taxation system.

The Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard) made a pathetic response to the Budget. As I said before, the Opposition treats the electorate as mugs. There were no specifics in his reply, no comprehensive alternative tax policy. If we want to know what the Opposition might do we have to go back to the last election. We will always remember the big grab for the pocket, the promise of the top tax rate of 38c in the dollar and the bottom tax rate of 25c in the dollar-that is, increase the taxes for the people on low incomes and reduce the taxes for the people on high incomes. If we go back to the last election period we will see some of the commentary made about the taxation policy of the Liberal Party during that time. We have to do that because that is the only way we can look at what it might do in the area of taxation. There are no specifics coming from the Opposition at present. In an article in the Daily Telegraph on 11 June last year headed `The sound of rubbery figures . . .', reporter David Armstrong had this to say about the Leader of the Opposition's tax policy:
Along with Mr Howard's voice you could hear the sound of rubber stretching. And the rubbery figures have given the Government a catapult to fire rocks at the Grand Plan.

How right he was. There was a journalist listening to the Leader of the Opposition bringing down his tax policy. He knew that the figures were rubbery. We all know-history has so recorded-that the figures were rubbery to a great extent and, of course, were exposed by the Treasurer in that election campaign. But nothing has been said since that election campaign which would lead us to believe that the Opposition would do anything different. As I have said, if we want to look at what it might do on taxation we have to go back to that time.

Cutting government spending is another line we hear from the Leader of the Opposition. So let us look at his record when he was in government. An article by Max Walsh in the Sydney Morning Herald during the election campaign was headed `The election promises of a ``taxer not an axer'' '. Central to the taxation policy in the last campaign by the Liberal Party was the claim that it would slash government spending. What did it do in its time? Max Walsh said in that article:
In his five Budgets, Mr Howard-
when he was Treasurer-
lifted Government outlays from 28.4 per cent to 30.4 per cent of GDP, an increase in 7 per cent over the period.
Over the same period he lifted taxes from 25 per cent of GDP to 27.7 per cent of GDP, an increase of 11 per cent.

So we can see when we match the rhetoric with the record that the rhetoric says `lower taxes, slash government spending' but the record suggests something else. When Opposition members get into office they do not have the guts to go on with it. It is all right to have a hairy chest when one is in opposition and to say what one intends to do, but being in government and actually doing the hard things that this Government has done takes a bit more guts than the honourable member for Bennelong was prepared to show when he was in government.
Of course the ultimate event happened. In the Age of 18 June the headline read `Keating destroys Lib tax pledges'. The article read:
The central proposition is that Mr Howard has `double counted' the general program cuts of $2,500 million and the $1,500 million cuts to the States against the same Commonwealth expenditures.

So there we have it. The rubbery figures that Mr Armstrong gave in his article after he listened to Mr Howard deliver his speech have caused the ultimate cut-down and, of course, the Leader of the Opposition never recovered. The fact is that Opposition members have never sat down and done the hard work of coming up with the policies.
After the Budget another journalist, Mr Burrell from the Age, posed a question to the Opposition. He said this:

A $5.5 billion surplus, a zero net borrowing requirement for the public sector, a 12 per cent investment forecast, cheaper beer and lipstick for Mr and Mrs Average and the biggest personal tax cuts in history to come. With the clothes they wore to the 1987 election well and truly stolen, where could John Howard and Andrew Peacock go?

That is a relevant question, because those are the sorts of things that the Opposition promised during the election campaign-not that it could ever deliver, as the Treasurer rightly pointed out. Mr Burrell goes on:
In an interview with The Australian Financial Review, the Shadow Treasurer, Mr Peacock, was pleased to suggest personal tax cuts-around $56 a week-
honourable members should remember what I said about treating the electorate as mugs-
for average earners to make up for the absence of tax scale indexation since 1983. He would not say how large the necessary spending cuts would be or where they would be made.

So there we have it-ambiguity all the way along the line clouded all in grey; no specifics, just treat the electorate out there as mugs. That is what the shadow Treasurer was doing in this interview. Mr Burrell goes on:
To pay for personal tax cuts of the order suggested would cost about $10 billion, spread over three years. Add to this the erosion of some of the $1 billion in fringe benefits tax-
the Opposition will give that tax back to its mates-
revenue from the changes proposed by the Opposition, the impact of its more generous capital gains tax-
once again, giving money back to its mates-
and the need for a bigger surplus, and we are looking at additional spending cuts as high as $15 billion on present figures.

That is what the Opposition wants us to believe-that it will cut government spending by $15,000m. Honourable members should remember what I said previously about the billboards down in Melbourne-`Taxes down, living standards up'. Anybody in Victoria, or indeed in Australia, should think hard about a Federal Liberal Party and its State counterparts in Victoria talking about raising living standards when taxes go down. The simple fact is that it cannot be done. The Opposition knows that it cannot be done; it is just a big con job. Mr Burrell asked a question of the shadow Treasurer:
Where would these cuts be made?
The shadow Treasurer replied:
The most significant contributor will be the health programme. But I am not prepared to detail the other areas we have examined.

Let us look at the outlays on health in the Budget. In the Budget Papers this year we find that the outlays are $10,797.3m. If we then look at the Medicare payments on page 122 we find that these amount to $3,725m. It seems to me that the Opposition wants to get rid of Medicare. It seems to think that that will save it $3,725m. The fact is that it will not. The health insurance system still has to work. Just slashing $3,725m off the Budget would mean that people would have to take out more costly private insurance to do what Medicare has already done. The function does not disappear, even though the money goes from the Budget Papers. The shadow Treasurer is saying that the Opposition will make significant cuts in the health area. He is really saying that he will get rid of Medicare.

Medicare is the most comprehensive and fair system of medical insurance that this country has ever had. It has an approval rating of 65 per cent, yet the shadow Treasurer wants to get rid of it. People in Victoria should really think about how well off they would be without Medicare, because the simple fact is that replacing it with private health insurance would be beyond the reach of certainly the two million Australians who never had private insurance before we came to power and also to a significant number of people beyond those.

Another area which the Opposition might look at is education. It might give the function of higher education back to the States. But the function does not disappear even though the money disappears from the Budget. That function is still there. It seems to me that through all this debate on the Budget, through all the election campaigns, including the one that is going on now, there is one consistency by the Liberal Party. Liberals have always argued for lower taxes and lower government spending, even though their rhetoric never matched their record in government. They have always treated the electorate as mugs. They always want the electorate to believe that people can have higher living standards with lower taxes. The simple fact is they cannot. As long as the Liberals want to espouse that line, they will sit on the Opposition benches, where they deserve to be, because they are nothing more than frauds. As a member of this Government, it gives me a great deal of pleasure to support the sixth Hawke Budget, which will do a lot of good for the Australian public. Even though the honourable member for Bradfield (Mr Connolly) frowns, that is true and, because of that, I will be here for a long time yet.
