SPEECH.SPEAKER: Smith Mr W.

TALK.START.PARA: —The honourable member for Canning (Mr Gear) says that he welcomes the sixth Hawke Budget. This afternoon I want to spend some time talking about one aspect of the Hawke-Keating Budget which in my view, and the view of many within the Australian community, marks yet a further decline in one vital area of government support, and that is in the area of science. Anyone who has been reading the newspapers closely over the last six months will have noticed a marked increase in the number of times there have been letters to the editors from eminent Australians-the best and brightest in this country, the researchers, those who spend years in laboratories looking for ways to solve very complex problems, the ones who are saying it is no longer worth going on because the Government does not care any more. This Budget marks a very marked and continued decline in Budget expenditure from the Government in support of science in this country.

SPEECH.PARA: Indeed, when I spoke on this issue last year I pointed out that for the first time in 15 years in this country we had seen the dismantling of the Department of Science at the Federal level. We no longer have a science department. We have a science Minister and he is a good Minister. He is a good advocate for science. But the tragedy of Barry Jones-and those in the science community confirm it-is that no-one listens any more; certainly no-one in his own party listens. That is a tragedy for all of us.

The main elements of science have now been spread to the four winds of the bureaucracy. The Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation is now under the jurisdiction of the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce, Senator Button. The Bureau of Meteorology-all about climate, that vital thing-is under the jurisdiction of the Minister for Administrative Services. The premier bicentennial scientific event in this country was the launching of the Australia Telescope. That now comes under the jurisdiction of the Minister for Employment, Education and Training. There is no longer in our community, at least at the Federal level, an advocate for science. Because of that, there has been a rapid decline in support for it in this country.

The Hawke Government is clearly failing to actively encourage and support the development of a lively science culture in which scientific creativity is valued, nourished and allowed freedom of expression. The Government has failed to provide the necessary financial commitment in support of major Commonwealth scientific bodies and a brain drain is already under way. The low priority given to science is evidenced, as I have said, by the axing of the Department of Science and the relegation of the major components of science to ministries other than the designated Minister for Science, which in itself is surely an absurdity. The Government is putting emphasis on short term, high tech, applied and `relevant' research at the expense of research in traditional areas such as rural research and basic research. There is an assumption by the Government that it can pick the winners in research, which is itself a huge gamble, in its intervention in directing research funds.

Interestingly, last year the Minister for Science said in an address at the University of Melbourne that the relations between science and government were improving and that `Australian science could be poised on the brink of the most important and most productive period in its history'. Nothing could be further from the truth. By September this year the Minister was saying that the Government's focus was too narrow and concentrated on the immediate, the financial and the obvious. How right he is. What happened this year in the Budget is further evidence of that.

Honourable members will know that the flagship of science in this country is the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation. Many of us, on both sides of this chamber, have expressed our concerns about the direction of the CSIRO. Over a five-year period there has been a cumulative reduction in funding to the CSIRO of some 32 per cent. Only several weeks ago we saw the unprecedented step taken by the divisional heads of the CSIRO of attacking the Chairman of the CSIRO for his comments that they were bad managers and his implication that they were not interested in the development of science in this country. I can well understand their indignation. As the former shadow spokesman in this area, I spent a considerable period visiting the various CSIRO establishments. It disheartens me as an Australian, let alone a politician, that people who have committed their lives to science feel that they have to leave.

If people can get excited about science-and I wish that they would-I direct them to what is outlined in the article that appeared on page 2 of today's Australian. It is indicative of what is happening. It was headed, `CSIRO's livestock chief quits over fund cuts'. It is the thin edge of the wedge. Here is a man who has given the best part of his productive academic life to science and the CSIRO saying that he has had enough, that no longer can he sit in the chair as a divisional head in the vital area of livestock and have to cut off the careers of young scientists in their prime, when they should be providing the very best of advice to Australia, saying, `Sorry; because of the government cuts no longer is there going to be a job here for you'. The article stated that Dr Trevor Scott, who had headed the animal production division based in Prospect in western Sydney for 14 years, said that his division had sustained real budget funding cuts of more than 50 per cent in the past six years. That is in the area of livestock support, of trying to find scientific ways to improve productivity within the vital area of beef exports.

How many times do members of parliament from both sides stand up and talk about the value of our agricultural produce and the benefits it brings to Australia? We all know of those benefits. If we want to improve productivity and maintain our competitive edge in the increasingly competitive world of international trade, we must be out in front. We must utilise the resources we have, our brain power, to give us advantages to get our produce to the markets in the best and most efficient way. Involvement in the livestock area by the CSIRO has produced tremendous benefits over a long period. It is an absolute disgrace that the division has now lost its divisional head, but it is indicative of what is happening generally. There have been other cases of scientists leaving. As recently as the end of August a mathematician by the name of Adrian Badderley left the CSIRO and wrote a very long article in the Melbourne Age indicating why. He said:

The word `basic' has become a bad word in Australia, but in the Netherlands, a nation with two-thirds of Australia's population, there are two research bodies like the CSIRO, one devoted to basic research, the other to applied research.

He will be working for the former. He is leaving Australia, going elsewhere to pursue his scientific career. A man whom this community has invested thousands of dollars in has turned his back on Australia, not because he does not love Australia but because he feels that no-one in this country cares any more, no-one in this Government cares enough to make sure that the funding levels of CSIRO are realistic. CSIRO is not asking for the world. It is just asking for sufficient funds to make its research programs viable.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Minister. I urge honourable members to look at the table. As I was saying, the scientists are leaving and CSIRO is suffering. It is interesting to reflect on a little bit of history about the CSIRO. It decided that the CSIR, or Council for Scientific and Industrial Research, ought to be set up. That was in the 1920s. A small committee chose the inaugural person to head this body, a man called Sir David Rivett. I might add that he was born in Tasmania, though a Victorian Rhodes scholar. A scientist was chosen to lead the science community to assist in utilising government funds to support science and to address the needs of an economy that was in a parlous state. These scientists chose particular areas to develop, and they chose those areas in which Australia had a comparative advantage. SPEECH.PARA: Relevant to the foreign aid grants in the recent Budget, I wish to speak about a country in the southern half of Africa where the indigenous black people are ruled by a racial minority who came from the north nearly three centuries ago. This minority, less than 15 per cent of the population, reserves virtually all power, all privilege and disproportionate amounts of wealth for itself. This country is ruled by a dictatorship of institutionalised racism. An example of what I am talking about occurred in 1972 after the majority tribe, which makes up 85 per cent of the population, had unsuccessfully challenged the minority Government, which brutally oppresses it. The Government forces set out to kill every man, woman and child from the majority group who had more than a primary school education. Teachers, administrators, clerks, priests and students were rounded up and slaughtered, first with bullets and later with clubs and hammers. Government extermination squads moved into the schools, picked out all the children of the majority race and smashed their skulls with sledgehammers. The children's battered corpses were later piled in heaps. In total, somewhere between 100,000 and 350,000 people were killed.

Honorable members may have heard nothing of this atrocity. That is not surprising, since not one single peep of protest came from the United Nations about it. Nor has there been protest from the Organisation of African Unity, which loves to trumpet its concern about racism and rights. The British Broadcasting Corporation said nothing and the World Council of Churches was also mute. No Commonwealth conference listed the event on its agenda, and even that world conscience of human racism, the anti-apartheid movement, uttered not a murmur. There were no demonstrations or rallies in Western capitals; no playwright or songwriter immortalised the event; no epic film was made to condemn the massacre; and, even more amazing, not even Bob Hawke or Malcolm Fraser--

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member will not refer to the Prime Minister in that way.

—I take your point, Mr Deputy Speaker. I was referring to events in 1972 when he was not the Prime Minister. Not even those well-known latter-day champions of the black cause saw fit to mention this gruesome incident. I guess they had other things on their minds in those days.

SPEECH.PARA: Likewise, our ever vigilant Australian Broadcasting Corporation chose not to report such news, and somehow even the trade union movement neglected to call for the usual trade bans against the country. In the world outside the country in which this barbarity occurred, not one person shed a tear for the fallen victims and their grieving families. Perhaps the explanation for the selective censorship lies in the fact that the country to which I refer is Burundi and not South Africa. After all, there is little mileage to be gained from criticising the ruling black Tutsi minority in Burundi. Even though they rule the majority Hutu tribe, and do so solely by racial criteria, to condemn the Tutsi minority on the world stage is not considered fashionable. The Malcolm Frasers and others of this world have been quick to recognise that it is more fashionable to criticise a white minority of 17 per cent in South Africa than to condemn a black minority of 14 per cent in Burundi. I will return to that irony shortly.

Let us just dwell for a moment on a few of Burundi's facts and figures. Burundi is a tiny country of about five million people located in the central south-east area of the African continent. It is squeezed between Tanzania to the east, Zaire to the west and Rwanda to the north. At 27,834 square kilometres in size it is little more that 20 per cent of the size of my electorate of Parkes. Nevertheless, it has a 33-inch rainfall, which is about 825 millimetres, and 51 per cent of its land is arable; so it is potentially a very rich country despite its high population density. After gaining independence from Belgium on 1 July 1962 it, like so many African countries, has worked its way towards a one party, quasi-military socialist state and, as a consequence, has been going downhill ever since. Today, the average income of a Burundian is around $US5 a week. Coffee makes up over 80 per cent of Burundi's exports. Although the indigenous Hutu constitute nearly 85 per cent of the population, they are ruled by the Tutsi minority of less than 15 per cent. Incidentally, the Tutsis are the tallest race of people on earth. Their minority rule in Burundi, which is based entirely on race, is ruthlessly applied.

I would like to contrast the world silence on the Burundi racism and the massacre to which I referred with another country to the south that has also practised racism and whose history is also scarred by an incident of bloodshed. I refer to South Africa and the Sharpeville massacre. Let us recall for a moment that sad event. Back on 21 March 1960, whipped into a frenzy by the pronouncements of the South African Communist Party and their African National Congress and Pan African Congress cadres, some 10,000 shouting and screaming Africans marched on the local police station at Sharpeville. They were armed with sticks, clubs, knives, bottles, iron pipes, needle swords and other weapons. Photographs will attest to the massive piles of these implements that were collected after the shootings. The handful of police officers in charge of the station panicked and opened fire. It was both a tragic and a stupid action. I guess that it is easy for us to be critical after the event as we were not there. Nevertheless, when the shooting stopped, 69 lay dead. The world, naturally enough, was horrified by what had happened and, quite properly, condemned the circumstances of racism that had led to its occurrence. That is only as it should be.

However, nowadays the Sharpeville massacre, as it has come to be known, is annually paraded before the world as an atrocity committed by the South African police. While I agree that it would be hard to pardon what happened, I wonder why we give such prominence to this single event yet ignore the countless millions slaughtered like cattle in Russia, Vietnam, Cambodia, Afghanistan, Uganda or Ethiopia, not to mention the horrifying episode referred to earlier that took place in Burundi in 1972-12 years after the Sharpeville massacre.

Is there some sort of selective morality operating out there which dictates that the shooting of 69 blacks by police in South Africa in 1960 is a more heinous crime than the slaughter of 100,000 or more blacks in Burundi in 1972? Even if one accepts the implied logic of the anti-apartheid movement that to be killed or oppressed because of racism is worse than being killed or oppressed for other reasons, that is still no explanation as to why Burundi is exonerated and South Africa prosecuted. Both countries are racist. Is it because the ruling South African minority is anti-communist and the ruling Burundi minority not as strongly so? Perhaps. Such reasoning could have explained why the United States of America was vilified in Vietnam while the Russians were overlooked in Afghanistan.

However, I suspect that that is not the prime factor operating here. I think there is a much more basic and sinister force at work. In fact, I believe that force to be based on colour. Regrettably, it appears that the great bulk of the anti-apartheid movement judges black people to be morally inferior to whites. I find this appalling and repulsive. Surely it is a basic human right that all people have equal rights and should have equal responsibilities to accompany those rights. People who commit acts of atrocity should be equally condemned, irrespective of whether they are black, white, red or yellow. A person who dies at the hand of a black is just as dead as one who dies at the hand of a white. It is a patronising sort of racism to apply a higher standard of behaviour to a white than to a black. If we are all equal we should all be judged equally and by the same standards. This treatment by the anti-apartheid movement of the holocaust in Burundi as just some sort of messy incident between some sort of lowly, uninteresting people that are not worth worrying about, I find both racist and hypocritical.

Honourable members will be aware that the dominant Tutsi tribe has recently been on yet another racist murdering rampage of the Hutu indigenous peoples of Burundi. Most reliable reports have it that about 24,000 Hutus have been slaughtered. Burundi's leader, Major Pierre Buyoya, admitted last month that his soldiers had killed Hutu civilians on sight as a reprisal, he said, for their massacring of Tutsi tribesmen in ethnic clashes. He claimed that his soldiers had done it spontaneously without any order from the Government.

As well as these 24,000 revenge killings which, incidentally, must surely give the word `overkill' a macabre new meaning, some 41,000 or more Hutus have fled into neighbouring Rwanda. Many have arrived with bayonet, knife and bullet wounds and with stories of how the soldiers killed so many of their race. Some newspapers ran a few stories on these latest massacres, albeit on pages 9 or 10, well away from the front page and second page headlines which I see were reserved for Nelson Mandela's latest illness. Of course, there has been the usual deafening silence on the Burundi racial massacres by the usual array of anti-apartheid dignitaries and organisations. I guess that they still regard them as inconsequential happenings of no great import.

However, while the anti-apartheid clique are, no doubt, chattering in the foyers about the latest glossy anti-South African film, or preparing for next year's Sharpeville massacre remembrance, the Burundi refugees pouring over the border into Rwanda are each describing the loss of up to eight relatives. The victims, because they have been chosen on racial lines, are nearly all Hutus.

The world has also chosen to overlook that napalm has been used on the Hutu population from Government helicopters. People on the Rwanda border have lost count of the number of bodies floating down the river into that country. Reports have it that the slaughter may still be continuing. Pregnant women have miscarried through sheer terror. Some of the accounts at a university hospital in Rwanda with 80 such patients are revealing. One of these accounts was from Mrs Mihimpudu, a 22-year-old mother who was shot through the wrist and had a puffy, burnt face. She sat on the bed, naked to the waist, when she gave her account to the reporter. She said that the soldiers had made her and nine villagers lie on the ground and then shot them. Both her children died and her baby, who was strapped to her back, was shot through the head. The doctor at the hospital has performed 20 amputations in the last week. Fifty out of the 80 patients had as many as 20 bayonet wounds each, so the reports go. One woman had an infected hole in her breast left by a bullet that entered from her back. A 17-month-old baby girl had a bullet wound through her jaw. Her mother had also been shot in the face and her father killed. A 2 1/2-year-old boy sat up in bed, his right arm held by his father. His left arm had been amputated at the shoulder after being shattered by a bullet. His mother, brother and sister had been killed. In another bed were two eight-year-old girls. One had been bayoneted in the back while she was lying on the ground and the other had machete wounds to the hands and neck. `It was the soldiers', she said. However, they were not all Hutus. There was an eight-year-old Tutsi boy there with his face smashed by a machete. His mother said that his father had been killed. In one area in the Ntega district, hundreds of houses are deserted, some burnt. Almost the entire population has been killed or has fled. The area is deserted.

A tragedy has occurred in Burundi and is continuing to occur. Perhaps it is not a fashionable country and perhaps it has not received much publicity in this country. Nevertheless, I believe that international aid is needed, especially in Rwanda, to assist these refugees that have fled from Burundi. More importantly, world pressure must be brought to bear on the Government of Burundi so that it will hold internationally supervised democratic elections and pressure must be brought to bear to get rid of the racially oppressive system there. I hope that Australia will get its perspectives and priorities right and lead the way with such long overdue initiatives.

SPEECH.PARA: I would like to address my remarks to some aspects of the Government's economic policy and in that context to raise a couple of issues that I had hoped to raise during the matter of public importance debate today but unfortunately did not have time to do so. I did advert to the Victorian Government's record in manufacturing industry and I indicated there that this was of particular importance in my electorate of Maribyrnong in the western suburbs of Melbourne. In the last two years manufacturing exports from Victoria have increased by 120 per cent, which I think most honourable members would be aware is about twice the rate of the rest of Australia. That has significant implications for the western region of Melbourne, relying as it does so heavily on manufacturing industries. I think it is one of the important indices in judging the combined efforts of the Federal and State Labor governments, in particular the priority given to export enhancement and import replacement. If one looks at the introductory remarks to the Budget, it is obviously a key ingredient of the Government's strategy and a very successful one at that.

In the contemporary political debate in Victoria, obviously the State Opposition has not been able to register a mark against the Government's economic performance, and one would not wonder at that if one went through the range of indices that ought to be taken into account when looking at the performances of a government. Mr Kennett's claims that Victoria is the highest taxing of the Australian States are probably another symptom of the chronic inability of the Opposition to get its sums right. I suppose by way of comparison, all things being relative, one can only reflect on the absurdity of that criticism in the light of what happened in the lead-up to the last Federal election. The Liberal component of the Opposition-the party in disarray-was advocating tax cuts of the order of $7 billion. The National Party of Australia was advocating tax cuts of the order of $14 billion. How any member of the Opposition can come into this chamber and talk about fiscal rectitude or commonsense government is beyond me when that contemporary record is fresh in the minds of the people of Australia.

In this case, as in many other cases, the Opposition's back of the envelope calculations are in direct conflict with the official Australian Bureau of Statistics measurements of government financial estimates. If one goes to those hopefully impartial documents rather than relying on the rhetoric that goes around this chamber in a pre-election environment, one will find, for example, that according to the Australian Statistician Victoria's per capita taxation in 1987-88 was $971. Because the Opposition was at pains to refer to the Greiner Government today by way of comparison across a range of indices, I might just compare that amount with the 1987-88 figure in New South Wales, which was $1,009, significantly different.

Even apart from the nonsense involved in the Opposition's numbers, the reality is that the whole basis of the Liberal Party's claims on State taxation is meaningless, and that is because it ignores the principle of fiscal equalisation which of course is enshrined in our federalism arrangements and which will always ensure that the less populous States appear to have the lowest per capita taxes. A more consistent and more appropriate measure of the share of a State's product being taken by the Government can be found in the statistics published in the Federal Budget Papers giving State own source revenue as a percentage of gross State product. Those figures show how much of the State economy each State government takes for its own purposes. The most up to date version was published on Budget night last month. I emphasise again that, where possible, one ought to go to the umpire in these matters. Those figures show that Victorian State Government own source revenue is the fourth lowest of the States. If State revenue per head is taken into account, Victoria goes one better again. On that measure it is the fifth lowest of the six States, bettered in that context only by South Australia.

It is not surprising to find that the State administered for the longest period by the Liberal Party of Australia, that is of course Tasmania, has the highest per capita revenue collections of all States. The Cain Government also shapes up well in keeping revenue increases to a minimum over the period from 1982-83 to 1987-88. The average real growth in Victoria's State own source revenue was the lowest of the six States.

If I recall correctly, the Deputy Leader of the Liberal Party (Mr Peacock), the shadow Treasurer, was at pains to take advantage of the last month's statistics in a particular context. I think I should emphasise again that any assessment of any government, be it Federal, State or regional, really relies upon an extended timeframe to ensure that statistical discrepancies do not give a distorted result. I emphasise again that over that extended period from 1982-83 to 1987-88 the average real growth in the Victorian State Government's own source revenue, the most appropriate index, was the lowest of the six States. Equally, average real growth in own source per capita revenue is lower in Victoria than in any of the other States. In other words, Victoria can justifiably and relying upon the umpire, if one can have an umpire in these matters, make the claim to have a low tax State. As I indicated, the rhetoric that surrounds the lead-up to a State election is in conflict with the umpire's data.

I also alluded to something which was not picked up by the mainstream media, and I hope the media used a bit of investigative capability to track it down. I was advised by an impeccable source that about two weeks ago Mr Ian McLachlan, the former President of the National Farmers Federation and long time member of the Liberal Party, indeed an individual who has been mooted on more than one occasion as a potential leader of the Liberal Party, described the Opposition in a public forum in Melbourne as `brain dead'. If the mainstream media track that down-I understand a journalist from the Weekly Times was present-that should provide the basis for a reasonable story. Again, that is not coming from someone like me with a clear subjective view about the Opposition. This gentleman joins a long queue of people in the Opposition parties who have been very frank about their shortcomings. I think the Australian people and for that matter the Victorian people are entitled to question why they should be requested to vote for an Opposition party which the former Leader of the the National Party described as being `in disarray' and a prominent member of the Party in a contemporary context described as `brain dead'. This is very hard hitting rhetoric but, in my subjective view, it is very accurate. I think the Australian people are entitled to add additional weight to those comments as they come from such impeccable sources in the Opposition itself. I think that those criticisms are manifest not only by any observance of the coalition in opposition but in terms of its contribution in this chamber and elsewhere.

There are a number of other points that I think are worth making. The genesis of the Opposition's matter of public importance today was a report in the Australian which had a bold headline with respect to the Victorian State Government's alleged indebtedness. In fact, if one drew a correlation between significant newspaper articles and the role of the Opposition in this chamber, that empirical data would suggest a very clear link between the main stories of the day and what subsequently transpires in this chamber. Of course, that means that we have an Opposition which relies primarily on the Press Gallery for its direction in this chamber. In my submission, that of itself shows a relative poverty of thinking within the Opposition. In my 51/2 years in this chamber I have not had the experience of the Opposition coming in here and canvassing the main policy issues that look beyond tomorrow's headlines. I think that is a very sad thing and a reflection of the mess that the Opposition is currently in. Perhaps that is one of the reasons why the former Leader of the National Party describes the Opposition as being in disarray.

I have already alluded to Victoria's debt but I think it is worth reflecting on a number of other points. No-one of any status in this debate has indicated that Victoria cannot well handle the existing debt that is part of any modern government. In fact, the rating agency Moody's Investor Services Inc.-which again I think I can describe as more of an umpire in these matters than I or anyone opposite, and which is regarded internationally as being if not pre-eminent in this area then certainly one of the two major agencies-has awarded Victoria the highest credit rating that any State government can possibly achieve. It is not the second or third highest but the highest. That independent arbiter of whether or not a State government's level of indebtedness is too high has given the Victorian Government the highest possible rating. The reason is that Victoria's debt is coming down and is just over half, in terms of debt to gross domestic product (GDP)-which is the appropriate index-what it was in the days of Sir Henry Bolte.

It was only a short time ago, at the Liberal Party's pre-election launch, that once again Sir Henry Bolte was trotted out. The Liberal Party implicitly and explicitly holds out Sir Henry Bolte as being a reflection of all that is good and proper in the Liberal Party. Given that in Sir Henry Bolte's period of office there was a level of debt to GDP double what currently transpires in the Victorian Labor Government context, I think that of itself is a significant ingredient in relation to proper debate, and it puts into perspective the Labor Government's record in that regard-which, obviously, is quite good. The growth of Victoria's debt service ratio-again, a most significant index-has been the lowest of all States since 1982. Of course, there are, as there always will be, lies, damned lies, and statistics. I suppose the National Party's version would be `pork pies, damned pork pies, and statistics'. People always have the ability to abuse statistical data, which is why I hope that I have been astringent in this debate rather than making assertions to try to appeal to sources that would be regarded by most Australians as being as close to the umpire as one can get.

By way of example, the debt figures in New South Wales are assisted by the fact that gas is produced in the private sector and electricity is distributed by local government. Of course, in Victoria they are both public sector State government functions, and they are very significant at that. In fact, they constitute a very significant proportion of the State Government's responsibilities. In 1988-89, Victoria's borrowings will be 38 per cent lower in real terms than in the last year of the former Liberal Government. I would have thought that, coming from an independent source, that is a fairly telling statistic. Victorian borrowings have fallen in each of the past six years, which is a rather unique phenomenon for a modern economy. The Cain Government has committed itself to ensuring that debt continues to fall as a share of the non-farm State economy during the term for which it will be elected next Saturday; and I have absolutely no doubt that it will be re-elected. In fact, I said to a Liberal Party colleague earlier today that certainly in the area that I represent I believe there has been a very dramatic shift in sentiment to the Labor Party over the last few months. I think that will be confirmed on Saturday not only in the western suburbs of Melbourne but elsewhere in Victoria.

I return to the core of the debate, that is, the economic analysis. By 1991-92 it is expected that the Victorian debt ratio will fall to 25 per cent, which will be the lowest level, not in the last five or six years, the period of the Labor Government, not in the last decade, and not even harking back to the so-called golden era of Sir Henry Bolte-which I indicated earlier was not all that golden when one looks at the empirical evidence rather than the supposed nirvana that the Liberal Party would have-but for this century. That is a most telling statistic and one that, unfortunately, we do not hear a great deal about. It is a rather unique statistic if one excludes the Federal arena. It is interesting that the Federal Opposition seeks to take up the cudgels on the issue of debt, because it was the current Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard) who, when Treasurer, removed the constraints on State borrowings. I can vividly recall, at least in economic journals, the debate that surrounded that decision. I think with the benefit of hindsight, particularly in terms of timing, it was a particularly unfortunate decision.

If one looks at the level of overseas debt that we have experienced in the recent past-and still experience-one will see that the State contribution is quite significant. In other words, in making that decision the then Treasurer, the new Leader of the Opposition, absolved the States of any responsibility in economic management. Through the Loan Council and other forums, it is very important in terms of macro-economic management to ensure that State public sector borrowing requirements are absolutely consistent with overall macro-economic objectives. Of course, he was also the Treasurer who left this Government with a $9.6 billion Budget deficit to rein in. We have certainly done that very well, and I think even members of the Opposition, in their quieter moments of reflection, would accept that.

SPEECH.PARA: I now turn to the Budget that was brought forward in August. I wish to debate those figures. I will begin by quoting Mr Terry McCrann, the respected economic commentator and journalist with the Melbourne Herald. He said:

By the middle of next year more than half of Australia's 7.4 million taxpayers will be 41c or higher tax bracket, paying more tax on each dollar of extra income than the corporate giants of Australia.

This situation brings about bracket creep, which is becoming more than just jargon used by tax experts. Every wage earner is feeling the pinch of the despicable policy of the Treasurer (Mr Keating) of reaping extra dollars from hardworking Australians. Australians will have to wait until 1 July 1989 to gain any relief from this tax increase brought about by inflation and wages growth.

In Budget Paper No. 1, in a very small paragraph relating to income tax on individuals, the figures support the proposition that bracket creep is the major factor in the Budget surplus of $5.5 billion. Income tax collections from individual pay as you earn taxpayers will grow by 13.8 per cent in 1988-89 compared with 8.8 per cent in 1987-88. These estimates are based on an employment growth for wage and salary earners of 2.5 per cent and, more importantly, on an estimated increase in average weekly earnings of 5.75 per cent. Put in simple language, Australian taxpayers will receive about a 6 per cent increase in their pay packets in the next 12 months but will pay nearly 14 per cent extra in tax. No wonder Labor's heartland is rejecting this high-taxing Government. The optimistic predictions of the 1988 Budget are based upon these tax increases. The States are carrying the burden of expenditure cuts. The Department of the Treasury takes the view that the five-year upturn in the world economic cycle will continue. There is a presumption that commodity prices will maintain their high levels of 1987-88.

The stormy clouds surrounding the United States economy with its rising domestic deficit of $US150 billion, along with a similar trade deficit of $US150 billion, make it imperative that the United States economic leadership take some drastic action after the presidential election in November 1988. There are signs that the stock markets around the world are becoming jittery, and that a second wave of selling similar to the October 1987 crash is not beyond the realms of possibility.

Whilst I commend the Treasurer for bringing about a domestic surplus, I am concerned that the predictions and background which make up the Budget figures are unduly optimistic. Australia is burdened with $110 billion of overseas debt, a high inflation rate, and a balance of payments problem that has yet to be corrected. With this background, let me destroy the myth that Treasurer Keating has dealt with the Australian economy in a prudent and fiscally responsible manner in his six Budgets. I seek leave of the House to incorporate in Hansard a table and graph from the Budget Papers which clearly indicate the deficits produced by Treasurer Keating in his first four Budgets.
Leave granted.
The table and graph read as follows-

0037C Mr McARTHUR-As sensible Australians will recall, the Hawke Government enjoyed an upturn in the world economy at the end of 1983, as well as the breaking of the drought. In this favourable climate, Treasurer Keating accumulated a deficit of nearly $23 billion. By his own reckoning in June 1986, Australia faced `a banana republic' status and the Government made some attempt to cut its extravagant expenditure patterns. Of course, capital sales, restrictions on State expenditures, and Reserve Bank windfall profits helped to turn the Budget around. During these years the economy continued to grow steadily. The shameful and outrageous lie that the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard) produced a $9.6 billion deficit in 1983 is totally rejected by the figures. With the ever present problem of escalating national debt, the Budget calculations should be put in the light of a possible fall in world commodity prices and a slow-down in the world economy. In September 1988 the signs are that this could happen. Australians are realising that in terms of national debt they are in the big league.

In Mr Des Moore's economic discussion paper No. 1, Australia's Debt Problem-How Serious?, he canvasses the problems facing Australia because of its escalating national debt position. Mr Moore is a highly regarded ex-Treasury official. When the Hawke Government came to power in 1983, the national debt was approximately $35 billion. Five years later it is now $110 billion. Mr Moore makes the following observation:
A country that is increasing its internal borrowings but does not in due course produce a commensurate increase in exports is clearly headed for double trouble.

He goes on to conclude that in fact we have not `increased our productive capacity to service that debt', that we have been on a consumption binge, and that, from all the subjective elements in this research, Australia's external debt ratios have clearly been too high since 1984. He says in his paper that Australia is in the category of `dangerously high debt countries rating twenty-seventh place in the list headed by Bolivia, Argentina, Peru, Brazil, Poland, Mexico, Chile, Ecuador and Egypt'. Further listed countries do not give comfort to Australia's position. Low debt countries on the scale are listed, with the United States of America in forty-eighth place, England in sixty-fourth place, and Singapore in seventy-sixth place, or top of the class in relation to its gross external debt commitments.

As many commentators have observed-and the Opposition has been alerting all Australians to the fact-this country now spends 40 per cent of its gross domestic product in servicing its international debt. The Budget predictions presume that commodity prices will hold their high levels. A review of their relativity and significance raises serious doubts about the capacity of commodities to maintain the buoyancy of the 1988 prices into the next 12 months. Quite clearly commodities are the key to Australia's future prosperity in terms of both overseas earnings and internal living standards. The Reserve Bank in its annual report of 30 June 1988 said:

While the rise in commodity prices is very welcome from Australia's viewpoint, it cannot be taken for granted that the levels of mid-1988 will continue for long. The higher prices should be regarded as a windfall which provides the opportunity to reduce markedly the balance of payments deficit. It would be tragic if they were absorbed in an overly rapid increase in domestic demand, with the pressures that would unleash, or if we were deflected from the long-term task of adjusting the structure of the economy.

Australia is totally dependent on major commodities contributing to our export earnings. In the last year, wool contributed $5.7 billion which constituted 14 per cent of our export earnings. It has been a dramatic increase on the income of two years ago. Wool growers are enjoying profitable incomes and, what is more, Australia is riding on the sheep's back as far as Treasurer Keating is concerned. Whilst the industry is anticipating about the same income in the current year, wool prices have fallen recently and if there is a dramatic collapse of the wool market this will have a major impact on the Budget outcome.

Coal makes a $4.8 billion contribution and constitutes 11.6 per cent of our export earnings. The archaic work practices and stubborn attitude of mining unions make the future profitability of this vital export industry questionable. Overseas competitors are offering quality coal at a price with certainty of delivery not impeded by unco-operative unions.

Aluminium and alumina have received a boost in price and contribute $3.6 billion which constitutes 8.6 per cent of export earnings. In my own electorate of Corangamite, the Alcoa Point Henry plant is helping this turnaround in the industry's profitability and Australia's exports. Gold, with a $2.4 billion contribution to exports, constitutes 6 per cent of export earnings and has been a big contributor to the change in commodity prices, moving upward to help the Australian economy.

The beef industry continues to enjoy prosperity as the drought in America provides a ready market and the Japanese market remains profitable and accessible. Twenty-three million head of cattle provide $2 billion worth of export earnings, constituting 5 per cent of total exports. The wheat industry provides a classic example of fluctuating fortunes both in production and in prices received. In 1983 after the drought 22 million tonnes were produced Australia wide and it is estimated that in 1988 only 14 million tonnes will be produced. In 1987-88 wheat generated $1.7 billion which constituted 4.2 per cent of exports. Prospects for wheat look better on the world scene because of the drought in the United States of America. Dairy products contribute about half a million dollars and help in providing rural prosperity for higher rainfall zones in Australia. The key element of these commodity prices is that added together they constitute 56.7 per cent of our total export earnings and that any change in their price will reflect directly on Budget predictions.

Turning to the balance of payments, I note that the Government has an ongoing problem with the $1.7 billion deficit figure announced on 28 August for the month of July. This adds to the already gloomy outlook. Australia has been trading in the red over the past two years and in 1986-87 was $13.2 billion in deficit. At the conclusion of 1987-88 another $11.9 billion was added to the red figures. The projection for the current year is $9.5 billion in deficit and in Senator Walsh's own words the nation's foreign debt and current account deficit is `the pall that hangs over the Australian economy'.

Whilst the media gave the impression that the Treasurer's Budget forecasts were favourable, there can be no doubt that in real terms the Budget is predicated on overly optimistic commodity prices. In the end it is hard working Australians-those highly taxed middle income earners-who have contributed a greater proportion of their livelihood to this insidious form of `tax by stealth'. It is they who have generated the $5.5 billion Budget surplus that the Treasurer has so proudly proclaimed.
