SPEECH.SPEAKER: Robinson The Hon I.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government's predicted $5.5 billion surplus in the 1988-89 financial year relies upon large revenue increases which are expected from collections of individual income tax, company tax, sales tax and fringe benefits tax. The Budget Papers show the extent to which increases in just a few areas of taxation have underwritten this year's huge surplus. Individual income tax, including capital gains tax, is predicted to rise by $5.7 billion in this financial year, an increase of no less than 13.6 per cent, which follows a healthy 10 per cent increase in the previous year. These figures clearly show the effect which the so-called incremental creep or fiscal drag has had on income tax collections.

SPEECH.PARA: Company tax is predicted to rise by no less than $1.4 billion this year, a 15.9 per cent increase, which follows a 31.1 per cent increase in the previous year. Sales tax is predicted to rise by $1.1 billion this year, a 14.4 per cent increase, which follows an 18.9 per cent increase in the previous year. We must recognise that this form of taxation is really tax by stealth. Sales tax has been indexed. We are now in our third or fourth year of this new form of taxation by stealth. There is never a clear indication of what the increases are. They are calculated and they automatically occur. It is no longer the responsibility of the Government front bench to come forward and say, `These are the increases as a consequence of the Budget determinations that will occur in this area'. That is a real deception.

The fringe benefits tax has reaped far more revenue than was estimated when it was introduced. Fringe benefits tax collections are predicted to increase by a further 13.6 per cent. Some of the areas where there are falls are interesting indeed. The biggest setback to revenue collections this financial year will come from crude oil and liquefied petroleum gas levies, which are likely to fall by 32.7 per cent, or $673m. The Government is trying to compensate for the drop in crude oil excise revenue by increasing levies on petroleum products, but this carries a heavy inflationary penalty. Every 1c increase in the petroleum levy adds 0.1 per cent to the consumer price index (CPI). That is the very thing the Government is trying to avoid. It is trying to find ways and means of keeping the CPI down whilst at the same time promising tax cuts and wage increases.

The Government cannot have it both ways. The truth is that there have been no real cuts in government expenditure, which were promised time and again by the Government. In the May mini-Budget and the current Budget the Government has cut funds heavily to State and local government. Those two areas account for about 95 per cent of the reductions that have taken place. This places a heavy burden on those levels of government. Taxation is increasing steeply. Many people are now entering higher income tax brackets. As a result of these effective tax increases, the ordinary taxpayer will have less disposable income available while they are facing increasing costs. This is a real area of concern that the Government is ignoring. The ramifications of this are reduced demands for goods and services, reduced incentive to work extra hours, which has an adverse impact on productivity, and reduced incentive for some to work at all. This is no way to manage the economy.

In the brief time at my disposal I draw attention to the fact that all the credit currently being taken for the reduction in our overseas commitments is being taken by the Treasurer (Mr Keating). The Treasurer is overseas saying that he is paying off a billion dollars here and a billion dollars there. Where has that money come from? It has come from heavy taxation within this country. But there is no effective policy to ensure that the consequences of the present Budget will mean an escape from higher interest rates and the risks that are inherent in the trends that can occur overseas, and there is no guarantee that at the end of the current financial year we will see a better overall position. In many respects there is no doubt that it is a risky Budget. It is said to be a soft Budget, but the truth is that it is not.

What does this mean for the man in the street? He has been blinded and deafened by the Treasurer's rhetoric-the promise of a better Budget, a better slice of the taxation cake at some future time. When is that to be? There is no firm commitment; there is no firm undertaking. But we can be sure it will be a political decision when the time comes. We find under the Government's education policy that there will be a cessation of the $263 higher education fee, but that will be replaced with a $1,800 debt to be incurred by those who are caught out by a means test, repayable by way of taxation at a later date. We have not seen the fine print for that proposal but no doubt it will again be rushed through this House, like so many other pieces of important legislation, to the detriment of the wider community. Again the Government has its own concept of who can pay and who cannot, having no regard to the real effects of means testing.

Many other areas of Government policy adversely affect the family. We must consider not only the traditional approach to education but also the Government's attitude to welfare services, to the whole range of important elements that have made this country what it is. We find in this day and age that those things are slipping away. We find that the disposable income of the average family is far less than it should be. We find that it is a tough battle for the middle income earner to survive against the Government's proposals.

Look at the realities of some of the Government's policies. There has been a slight increase in education funding. Of course that is desirable, and the intimation was that that funding would go towards technical and further education (TAFE) facilities and urgent training requirements. Let me refer to the demand for TAFE college facilities in my own electorate. There are around 1,000 TAFE students in the town of Maclean. They are being taught in halls and hired rooms, without adequate facilities. The New South Wales Government put forward, under the terms of the current arrangements for TAFE capital funding, a proposition for a new college. It was given No. 1 priority. Now we find that the Federal Minister for Employment, Education and Training (Mr Dawkins) has said no, northern New South Wales does not need such TAFE facilities and has refused to approve the proposition. As a result of a conference between the State and Federal Ministers, the question has been referred to consultants who will be commissioned to make a special investigation and come up with a report. In this day and age the responsibility for decisions of this kind should be taken by the Government, by the Minister and the department that he presides over. But, no, here we see delaying tactics, and it is just not good enough. These tactics will mean that it will cost even more to determine what the outcome should be.

Look at the rural sector, and at road funding and the traditional support for primary industry. Primary industry is currently carrying this country out of its economic dilemma to some extent. We find that this Government is cutting back on those few areas of support that primary industry has traditionally relied upon. Again that means a cost impost on the very industries that contribute so much to the overall outcome of a Budget of this kind. The Government's action is so contradictory that it is unbelievable that a responsible Prime Minister and a responsible Treasurer can seriously put a case of the kind this Government has to the people of Australia and expect to have it accepted. Look, too, at the other areas of real need-homes for the aged, preschools, and all of the responsibilities that fall upon the Commonwealth. We find the Government is creating barriers, hurdles and disincentives in these essential areas of Government spending. Yet the extravagant spending goes on. This extravagant spending in so many directions is unbelievable. So the Treasurer takes pride tonight, no doubt in yet another overseas country, in saying, `Look at my record, look at what I have achieved'. Of course he is covering up the real facts of where this Budget is taking this country. The strategy applied in this Budget is of no effective consequence at all.

TALK.START.PARA: —Before calling the honourable member for Hotham, I am sure I speak on behalf of all members when I say how pleased I am to see the honourable member for Riverina-Darling well and joining us in the chamber.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kent Mr L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am delighted to take part in this year's Budget debate as this is the best Budget introduced by the Treasurer (Mr Keating) since the Labor Government took office in 1983. The honourable member for Page (Mr Ian Robinson) tried to paint a gloomy picture of the economy and of the Budget. He bemoaned the fact that the disposable income of families is far less than it should be. He did not say what it should be. At the same time he is forgetting that only five years ago, under the Howard-Fraser regime, one million people in Australia had no income whatsoever. They were on the unemployment scrapheap. They had no income, disposable or otherwise. So let us not talk about disposable income. We are looking after the income of ordinary people by placing them in work. They have income today; they have a job to go to, thanks to this Government and thanks to the Treasurer.

SPEECH.PARA: The honourable member also said that the Government should reduce expenditure. But in the same breath he said he was very worried about the reduction in rural subsidies. Of course he does not say that we should reduce them, but that we should cut funding somewhere else. He wants to maintain subsidies for the rural community and reduce taxes. The rural people never like to pay taxes. I admit that I do not like to pay them either, but if we want subsidies we have to pay our taxes as well. We have to finance subsidies from somewhere.

As well as the Opposition putting forth all these contradictory points in its argument, it has also failed miserably in its attack on the Budget. It just could not fault it. I wish to join the majority of the economic commentators in Australia and congratulate the Treasurer on a very good Budget indeed. With a masterstroke the Treasurer brought down a Budget which lays the foundation for a return to an era of prosperity in Australia. The Labor Government has accomplished all this good work in only five years. We turned the economy from being one in a deep depression engineered by the Howard-Fraser regime in the early 1980s into an economy of growth. There was a Budget deficit of $11 billion when the Labor Government took office, and now there is a $5.5 billion surplus. This means in simple terms that the Hawke Labor Government, by turning an $11 billion deficit inherited from the conservatives into a $5.5 billion surplus in five years, has saved this nation an average of $3 billion each year it has been in office.

It is not only the billions of dollars that we have saved for this nation; we have also saved over a million people from the untold misery of unemployment. We have created jobs for them, and the effect of that has been felt especially in Victoria. In my electorate one can see operating factories that only a few years ago were idle because of the policies of the conservatives. Of course people are working in them. There are busy shopping centres, with people spending. People are earning money to spend on their needs and their families' needs. So it no wonder that the majority of Australian people support the Hawke Labor Government. I am also certain that the majority of Victorians will acknowledge Labor's achievements and vote for the Cain Labor Government in Victoria on 1 October.

Most economic commentators agree, and there is no doubt about it, that our economy is in good shape and in good hands. Thank heaven and the Australian people, the conservatives are cast onto the Opposition benches and cannot harm the economy of this country any more. However, they still intend to cause us damage in another area, namely, in the field of immigration and ethnic affairs, and of course, that is a very important area. It is a vital area, as the future of our nation depends on our immigration program. It is part of our nation building, as today's immigrants will be tomorrow's Australians.

Until now our immigration program has been uniquely successful. Nowhere else on this planet have so many people from various backgrounds settled so successfully in such a short time. I am a product of this migration program. I am only a first generation Australian and, if the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard) or anyone else wants to suggest to me that I am not serving this nation well as a member of this Parliament because I am not of Anglo-Celtic background, I will be deeply offended. My wife and I were born in Yugoslavia, we came here 35 years ago; my son married an Australian of Irish descent. Does the Leader of the Opposition want to say that my grand-children are not `dinky-di Aussies'? If he tries that on them, he will get a kick in his backside. Does he want to judge me on my ancestry, does he want to judge my grandchildren on their ancestry, or is he objecting to migration from Asia only?

What vision does the Leader of the Opposition have concerning the current and future generation of Australians? Does he consider that only Australians of Anglo-Celtic descent have the right to nominate migrants to this country? Does he want to deny the same rights to Australians of Vietnamese, Cambodian or Chinese origin? If not, I call on him, as our Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) called on him, to retract and to apologise to those in the community whom he offended by advocating racist attitudes concerning immigration. He was talking on `One Australia', but he was advocating the exclusion from the `One Australia' those whom he considered racially inferior, namely, people of Asian background. One would have to pause for a moment and ask: Why would the Leader of the Opposition single out people of Asian background?

Does he have any reliable statistics to show that there is something wrong with our migrants from Asia, be it Vietnam, Cambodia, the Philippines, Singapore or Hong Kong? Can he give any reason why Asian migrants would not fit into our way of life? Of course, he has no such statistics, and the only reason he advocates the slowing down of the Asian immigration is to play to the racist gallery in the hope of winning a few votes. It was for the basest opportunistic reasons that he decided to fan the racist flames.

Let us be rational and ask ourselves what kind of society we are. Of course, we pride ourselves on being a society where good family life is highly rated, where human rights and the freedom of the individual are highly respected, where individual ambition to better ourselves is encouraged. Would anyone want to say that these values are not shared by our migrants from Asia? Are they or are they not good family people, or does Howard want to say that they do not value the freedom of individuals when thousands of them fled from their homeland, exposing themselves to personal danger and suffering just because they value personal freedom so highly? Is anyone accusing our Asian migrants of opposing individual initiative and not being ambitious to better themselves? Of course not. So, what is all this `hoo-ha' about `social cohesion'? I have yet to see any group amongst our migrants who do not share our values and do not support the basically Anglo-Celtic way of life and institutions of our society. While Australians of Anglo-Celtic descent support our institutions of parliamentary democracy, freedom of trade unions, freedom of the Press, respect for human life and freedom of the individual and so on, out of tradition, brought with them from the mother country, we, migrants of non-Anglo-Celtic background, respect those same institutions and traditions, not for sentimental reasons, but because they are good institutions and good traditions.

I mention with pride that it was not a coincidence that I was the first and most vocal opponent in my Party and in this Parliament of the introduction of identity cards. It was not a coincidence; it was because I learnt from generations of Australians to respect the individual and the freedom of the individual. I strongly believe that, should those institutions and freedoms that I mentioned before be by any chance in jeopardy in future, migrants together with their fellow Australians will man the barricades to defend them-and so will our children, together with the children of fellow Australians, give their life in defence of our country should the need arise. So, let us not talk about who will or who will not fit into our society as, by such talk, we only introduce divisions into our nation, divisions that are imaginary and really do not exist, except in the minds of xenophobic eccentrics or racists.

The Leader of the Opposition used the code word `social cohesion', implying that Asian migrants are not suitable for acceptance into our society. He and his supporters in the National Party may have their likes and dislikes of various groups of migrants, be they Asian or others; but that matters little in this debate. The central point is that if racist sentiments are given legitimacy by a major political party our reputation as a civilised nation will be damaged, not only overseas but also in our own eyes.
The damage done by the Leader of the Opposition overseas as well as in Australia was well expressed in our Press. Let me quote from an article by Peter Cole-Adams in the Age of 6 August 1988:

This is apparently not enough for Mr Howard. With his double talk about `social cohesion', he seems to be opening the way for a partial return to the days of the 1950's and 60's, when we restricted our migrant intakes to those countries whose people were assumed to be, racially and culturally, most easily assimilable into a predominantly Anglo-Celtic host community.

If so, the international and internal implications will be considerable. Neighbouring nations will certainly notice, and be even more sceptical to our claims to be considered part of the Asian community . . .
Internally, the Howard rhetoric and the foreshadowed Howard policies are likely to increase the social divisions that he says he deplores.
I also quote from the editorial in the Australian of 12 August 1988:

If (the Coalition) conducts a campaign which concentrates on Asians, it must expect that it will be seen as racist and will forfeit the support of all those who reject racial discrimination as a return to barbarism.

Furthermore, the Leader of the Opposition's outburst not only is divisive as far as the general community is concerned but also has effectively created a deep division between the more decent elements in his own Party and the Tuckey-type opportunists, or do the Leader of the Opposition and his Party wish to return to the white Australia policy? Quite possibly. The latest news is that the Opposition now proposes to examine prospective migrants for the acquired immune deficiency syndrome, AIDS. What an insult! Has the Opposition any figures which would indicate that migrants are the carriers of this unfortunate disease? It would be so much more appropriate if it examined its former shadow Minister for Health for distemper.

The Leader of the Opposition was basing his comments partly on the report of the FitzGerald Committee to Advise on Australia's Immigration Policies. He was implying that the FitzGerald report had something to say against Asian immigration. Nothing could be further from the truth. Let me quote from that part of the FitzGerald report that deals with Asian migration, page 66, which reads:

Historically, Asian-born were among the earliest immigrants to Australia. Today, they mix extensively in the community as judged by inter-marriage, are a growing proportion of our intake, and come from countries with some of the fastest growing economies in the world.
In the one place where Vietnamese, for example, are most heavily concentrated in Western Sydney, they still only represent some 6% of the population.
The crime statistics of Asian-born are among the lowest of any group of overseas-born.

This issue must be also addressed against the historical background in which the largest national groups of immigrants have been the least popular, and in which much of what is now said of Asians was once said of Italians and Greeks and Maltese, and once also of Irish.
Surveys indicate that attitudes to Asian immigrants are in many respects more positive than to other European and non-European groups.

Australians have always expressed their reaction to newcomers irreverently and disparagingly, to the ``Pommie bastards'', ``Wogs'' and ``Dagoes'' who formed the successive waves of immigration, while welcoming the benefits they brought.
The Committee's research suggests that anti-immigrant sentiments may have been more hostile and more boisterously expressed in earlier times than in the past decade.
Surveys show that most Australians believe that policy discrimination, directed at Asians or anyone else, is not acceptable.

The real test is the test of social acceptance. Ten years of substantial immigration from Asia suggests very strongly that it is working. The commitment is apparent on both sides, and the harmony of outcomes is already evident. Government must not be complacent about this harmony, but work hard to ensure that it endures.

Obviously, the Leader of the Opposition had never even read the FitzGerald report when he made his comments. The Leader of the Opposition's misguided comments and his misguided and ambiguous policies certainly do little to ensure the harmony of our nation. To the contrary, his comments and policies have the calculated effect of setting one Australian against another. Whilst previous conservative governments have been divisive and have done that, never before has any leader in our political arena attempted to set one Australian against another on the basis of the colour of skin or racial origin.

I am sure that the Australian people will reject the attempt by the Leader of the Opposition to rekindle racist attitudes and intolerance in our society. I am also certain that they will condemn and reject those who wish to lend any respectability to racial prejudice and that they will reject the Leader of the Opposition for the same reason.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Connolly Mr D.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —This debate is almost bizarre. It takes place in an environment in which a Budget was introduced in this chamber on 23 August. Here we are, on 27 September, still debating an event which has been described by members of the Government as their greatest budgetary achievement since 1983. Despite the noted cant of the Treasurer (Mr Keating) and the comments he has made overseas in the last 48 hours, it is perfectly clear that the Treasurer is now warning major trading nations of the serious risks of a slowdown in world economic activity, risks which obviously will impact upon the Australian economy. Yet this Budget was based upon the most optimistic scenario that the Treasurer found possible to paint.

SPEECH.PARA: We have now experienced six Budgets under Labor. They have produced an Australian society that is more divided, more insecure, more cynical about the promises of politicians and more determined to seek answers to complex problems that are beyond the scope of our representative institutions than ever before. We must ask ourselves: Why is our society so divided under Labor, especially when the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) was elected on a platform of consensus? The reason we have this division is that the Government has deliberately set out to divide Australians. Over six Budgets it has established a society in which the very rich have become much richer and the average Australian family is fighting to be able to exist at all, and has watched its standard of living fall inexorably, year by year. The wealth of our country is in fewer and fewer hands than ever before. Mateship is no longer a term of pride and endearment. We forget that the word was part of our common heritage. It was indicative of the blood, sweat, toil and tears of our ancestors who opened up and built this nation. They did so by helping each other.

This Labor Government has made Australia a more introverted and selfish society. This has occurred because Australian families are battling to survive today as never before. They see around them only too clearly the true fruits of Labor's mateship: big government, big business and big unions. These factors together have conspired to usurp the sovereignty of the people who, in return, have been offered by Labor a diet of Marie Antoinette's cake and little else, in the form of yet higher and higher taxes. In return they have seen introduced in this House a so-called social justice strategy. What a meaningless term! Are all Australians being treated equally by this Government? Obviously, they are not.

Let us look at the realities of family life in Australia today. This Budget has given nothing to over 70 per cent of our families except higher sales taxes and yet another year of higher income taxes. By mid-1989 half of all Australian's 7.4 million taxpayers will be paying over 41c in the dollar in income tax-a record in our postwar history. But the Government says, `Don't worry. We promise you that next July, August, September or sometime you're going to get tax cuts'. We want to see whether those cuts will in any way compensate for the massive tax increases that the last six Budgets have imposed on the Australian people.

For the 28 per cent of Australian families who qualify for the family assistance supplement (FAS) the increase falls well short of the Government's benchmark of 15 to 20 per cent of the married pension rate. The Prime Minister's pledge, made to the people last July at the time of the last election, was that by 1990 no child will be living in poverty. The Minister for Social Security (Mr Howe) has not refuted the Australian Council of Social Service's claim that because the increases will not come into effect until next June, they are illusory. For example, a family with a child aged under 13 would get a rise of 10c per week-how generous!-instead of $2, and for children aged over 13 the rise would amount to 70c per week. Surely, this is yet another example of the pea and thimble trick, Keating-style.

Part of this is due to the Government's failure to index or increase family allowances. Since this social justice Labor Government came to power there has been a 30 per cent decline in the value of family allowances-that payment which reaches the vast majority of Australian families, and which was introduced by the previous coalition Government. The Government's rhetoric in the area of rent is interesting. It states:
A major package of housing assistance for low income families renting privately . . . It will make a significant contribution to alleviating housing related poverty.

That is what the Government said. Let us look at the reality. The Budget offered $5 extra, not this year, but in June 1989, and another $5 in June 1990. The result is that the average family in receipt of the FAS will get $25 in rent assistance in two years time. Those with three or more children will get $30 in two to three years time. The important point is that no suggestion was made that any of this would be subject to consumer price index increases. On current rates of inflation, therefore, that small increase will be approximately minus 7 per cent per year. Across the board increases in rent assistance via the FAS do little, if anything, to tackle the rent crises, largely in Sydney and Melbourne, which we are facing today. For families paying $290 per week, which is the average for a modest three-bedroom home in Sydney, and receiving $15 rent assistance, surely another $5 to $15 in June or July of 1989 or 1990 represents little more than a drop in the ocean.

What is this Government doing to solve these fundamental rental problems which were exacerbated by its own ill-conceived changes on negative gearing, which reduced investment in rental accommodation over recent years, effectively raising rents to catastrophic levels? Of course, in addition, we have further increases in housing rates and interest rates on housing yet again.

In the area of unemployment also, we are told by members of the Government that, in aggregate terms, the figures have fallen. We welcome that fact. But look at the detail of the policy. While we welcome the Government's commitment to reskilling and training, this year's Budget will help only 15 per cent of the total long term unemployed of 170,000. In reality, 25,000 extra places will be allocated through labour market programs which hardly equals the Government's rhetoric that `it will contribute to a substantial reduction in long term unemployment'. Rather, it raises false hopes with the unemployed being mere pawns in the Government's media games yet again.

The need for action on the long term unemployed is well overdue, with the mean duration of unemployment now standing at 66 weeks compared with 33 weeks in May 1982. That is a 100 per cent increase in six Budgets. In addition, there has been an increase in the numbers of families with children suffering long term unemployment. In May 1982, it was 16.5 per cent. In May 1988 the number had nearly doubled, to 31 per cent, with unemployment stuck on approximately 7.8 per cent and not likely to fall below 7.25 per cent, according to the Government's own estimates. Therefore 10 people are unemployed for every vacant job. The creation of 25,000 training places is clearly but the tip of the jobless iceberg. Unfortunately, this Labor Government has again failed to deregulate the labour market to the extent that is necessary. It has failed to take on and to face the reality of the conservative attitudes adopted by trade unions to the need for change, which is the surest way to increase jobs for all. The Government has refused to introduce a community service for unemployment arrangements even though it has at last recognised the need to combine passive income support with enhanced labour market activity, something the coalition has been advocating for years. Regrettably, this Government has been slow to move in this area.

In the area of sole parents, the Budget introduces in March 1989 what is euphemistically called the jobs, education and training (JET) program, with the fanfare that it would have a substantial impact on increasing work force participation by sole parent pensioners. In fact, the decision in the May statement last year to cut sole parent pensions for children aged 16 and over was lauded by the Government. It said that it would help sole parents enter the work force and break down the transition to work barriers. According to Department of Social Security estimates, the reality is that some 90 per cent of the 17,000 sole parents affected are on some form of benefit or pension today. An extra $2m was allocated then for training programs for those affected but Department of Employment, Education and Training Commonwealth Employment Service figures for September 1987 to June 1988 show that less than 6 per cent, or 1,000, of those affected have actually received any training at all, with a further 1.5 per cent going into the work force with the help of subsidised employment.

The report of the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Employment, Education and Training entitled Getting to Work, which was tabled in May, reveals the shocking mismanagement of the Government's decision to cut sole parents' income support when their children turn 16. It reveals the inability of the Department of Social Security and the Department of Employment, Education and Training to work together in the interests of those affected. The report also exposes the Government's earlier decision in 1986 to review sole parents once every month for the first month and every three months thereafter to ensure eligibility and to provide counselling on how to gain employment. It sounded marvellous. In fact, it reveals that there was, and is, no counselling being provided whatsoever. Does the Government seriously ask sole parents to believe its rhetoric on JET which, even if it becomes a meaningful program, will help only 5 per cent of the total numbers who would be eligible if it met its target of 12,000 places by 1990-91?

Let us move to the question of forgotten youth. Another great program with one of these marvellous name tags is New Start, which is targeted at the adult long term unemployed, that is, the over 21-year-olds. The 100,000 unemployed 16- to 20-year-olds have been left out and even the 23,000 who have been unemployed for over one year have been left out. There are no reforms of the youth homeless allowance which is widely regarded as a failure in meeting the needs of homeless youth. This is evidenced by requests for accommodation by 13,000 youths in New South Wales alone in the first six months of 1987 and the payment is reaching, on average, a mere 1,000 homeless youths across Australia.

The claim of the Treasurer that this Budget brings home the bacon, to use his expression on that memorable night, has a hollow ring in the ears of those who have no home and no future in this society, even if they could afford the bacon. For those over the age of 54, the likelihood of employment is also less than encouraging. These is no access to labour market training programs for the 40,000 Australians who are unemployed and have been for 12 months or more. The $5 extra in rent assistance in June 1990 for a pensioner without children has been described as `long overdue and inadequate' by the Australian Council of the Ageing. It also said:
Unless accommodation is secure, all other elements in the Budget are under pressure.

It is perfectly clear that the record of this Government in social welfare, in its attempt to achieve a so-called social justice strategy, is a shambles and a disgrace to this society. Although this Government states that it has compassion and it is concerned, society has no reason whatsoever to look upon the future with anything other than contempt.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cohen The Hon B.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy Speaker--
—Speak from the heart, Barry.

—I always do. The Budget brought down by the Treasurer (Mr Keating) on 23 August was easily the most extraordinary one that I have seen during my 19 years in this Parliament. When we recall the horrendous situation this Government inherited in March 1983 when, on coming to office, it found that the prospective deficit was around $9.6 billion and when we see that, this financial year, the Treasurer has budgeted for a surplus of $5.6 billion, it is even more extraordinary. I suppose that the achievement is best summed up by quoting a few lines from the Treasurer's Budget Speech:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . we are now systematically restructuring the economy, making Australia a much more dynamic place, more able to compete in the world.
The evidence is there for all to see.
This year our balance of payments deficit will be halved from its peak of just three years ago.
Our foreign debt burden has already stabilised and begun to fall.
Inflation is down.
Real wage increases are in prospect.
Our rate of job growth is unmatched in the Western world.
Business investment is rising rapidly.
On the export front, new manufacturing activities and tourism have blossomed.
On the import side, Australian factories are now supplying a wide range of goods that we used to buy from overseas.

In a little over 100 words, the Treasurer summed up both his and the Government's quite outstanding economic achievements. There is considerable personal satisfaction in three of those words, in particular the three that stated `tourism has blossomed'. When I first came into this House in 1969, I took a very serious interest in tourism. I took the time and trouble to read every speech made in this Parliament in the past 20 years. It was not a particularly edifying experience. Most speeches on the subject were motherhood statements in which the local member extolled the virtues of his electorate and wondered why governments were not spending millions of dollars to change his electorate into the tourist paradise of the South Pacific. The only significant action taken regarding tourism in that period-I am going back now into the 1960s-was the commissioning of the Harris Kerr Forster report in 1965 by the Menzies Government-a study into Australia's tourist potential. That was followed by more detailed studies into the Great Barrier Reef and the Ayers Rock and Mount Olga regions which ultimately resulted in the Yulara Village concept.

Tourism in the early 1970s was one of those subjects that everyone gave lip service to but little more. I was one of the few who had a passionate belief in Australia's tourist potential and I spoke on the subject on many occasions. The then Leader of the Opposition, Gough Whitlam-I am going back to 1972-asked me to prepare policy recommendations for the 1972 policy speech. In 1976 I managed to convince Prime Minister Malcolm Fraser to set up the House of Representatives Select Committee on Tourism which was announced in December of 1976. The work of that committee had a very profound effect on tourism in Australia when its recommendation that a 2 1/2 per cent depreciation allowance on new hotels was introduced by the Fraser Government. Those of us who saw the potential of tourism in those days were regarded by the majority of members with mild amusement. It was difficult for us to get the party executives on either side of the House to take it seriously. We argued then that it was not good enough for Australians to believe that they had a beautiful and fascinating country and that as a result millions would flock here. At the time, our accommodation by comparison with what was available in other major tourist countries was pretty ordinary. More importantly, we did not seem to realise that, fascinating as our heritage was, both natural and man-made heritage, our presentation of it was appalling.

Rather than go into a long description of the inadequacies of our tourist attractions and infrastructure in the 1970s, it is easier just to point out the fantastic new facilities that have been provided over the past decade. Kakadu National Park, Uluru National Park, including Yulara Village, the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park, including the Great Barrier Reef Wonderland, did not even exist 10 years ago. Yet look at the extraordinary improvement in those regions in recent years. I like to think that the 4 1/2 years that I was Minister had more than a little to do with those improvements. There are many reasons for the sudden surge in tourism, including the drop in the value of the Australian dollar, the terrorist scares in Europe and the Middle East, the Australian film industry which has done so much to promote Australia overseas, and of course the excellent promotional campaign initiated by my colleague, the former Minister for Tourism, the honourable member for Parramatta (Mr John Brown), who has the good sense to be in Seoul at the moment.

The Treasurer's long speech indicates that at long last the Government of Australia is taking the industry seriously. It recognises that it is not just a peripheral industry making a minor contribution to Australia's balance of payments but an industry that is a major factor in the Australian economy, its growth and its future. This is quite revolutionary, because in days gone by governments simply did not treat it seriously. The figures are so dramatic that we now find the Treasurer mentioning tourism in his opening remarks. That would never have happened five years ago, even three years ago. This year the anticipated number of tourists from overseas is 2.2 million and by 1995 the number is expected to rise to 4.5 million.

I have some figures that indicate the number of jobs that have been created. In 1987 some 430,000 people were employed in the tourist industry. By 1990 that is expected to rise to 533,000 and by 1991 to 639,000. This is a huge industry which is employing a large number of Australians and particularly the sorts of young Australians and old Australians who have been unable to get work because they lack the high technological skills required for many of the new jobs that have been created in industry.

We have to remember that it has not all happened by accident. The factors I mentioned earlier appear to have come together at just the right time. What we have to do is to recognise that to maintain, to increase and to meet the projected figures we cannot afford to sit back and hope it will happen. We must keep up the momentum. To do this the Government must ensure that the pattern of improvement over the past five or six years is maintained. It will not happen by itself. It will not happen just because we hope it will happen. I do not suggest for one moment that the Government is the only sector that should be responsible. Most of what needs to be done can be initiated by the private sector but there are things that only governments can do or where only governments can play a major role. For instance only governments can build the roads that are required for tourism, the airport terminals, the museums, the galleries, the national parks, the entertainment and the cultural centres. I will be dealing with that in greater detail later in this speech.

The Federal Government has more than played its part in bringing our tourist infrastructure up to the equal of anything in the world. To their credit, so have State governments. No better example of this exists than the achievements of the recent New South Wales Labor Government: the Sydney Entertainment Centre, Chinatown, the Powerhouse Museum, Homebush Bay, the Sydney Cricket Ground, the Sydney Football Stadium and the much maligned Darling Harbour. One of the great eyesores of the Sydney inner city area has been revitalised with convention and exhibition centres, Chinese gardens, a national aquarium, and later next year something with which I as responsible Minister was involved in setting up-the National Maritime Museum-will open, giving Sydney one of the greatest tourist attractions in the world. Anyone who has any doubts about the success of Darling Harbour need only go there any day of the week and see the thousands of visitors enjoying themselves. As for the opposition to the monorail, I cannot recall any issue on which the opponents have been more out of sympathy with public opinion. My personal view is that it is fantastic.

Sydney has been revitalised but so have many other cities. I am no admirer of the National Party in Queensland but I must pay tribute to the excellent revitalisation of the area near the World Expo site. With a new museum, art gallery and cultural centre, Brisbane is now decidedly a more attractive tourist destination than it was just a few years ago. The private sector has also taken up the challenge, and from one end of Australia to another exciting new resorts have sprung up, providing quality accommodation equal to anything in the world. Not all of them are my taste but taste is a very subjective thing. The Port Douglas resort, Yeppoon, Sanctuary Cove, Hamilton Island, the Fairmont resort at Leura, the proposed new Peppers on Sea at Terrigal in my electorate and near the electorate of the honourable member for Dobell (Mr Lee), the intelligent young man sitting here on my right, are all part of the exciting new developments that are occurring all over Australia. The private sector will build the hotels, the restaurants, the shops and provide many of the services that visitors expect and demand. Only governments can provide the infrastructure-the roads, the airports-and in most instances the national institutions that constitute such an important part of a nation's tourist attractions: its galleries, museums, theatres and cultural amenities.

A lot of people in government fail to understand what it is that attracts people to a country, what they come here for in the first place and what ensures that they have a good time. We in Australia have quite rightly believed that our greatest attraction is our natural beauty: our outback, our flora and fauna and our beaches. To a degree, of course, that is correct but for a long time we failed to realise that international visitors would not put up with the poor quality of accommodation and presentation of our natural environment. That has largely been overcome, although much still remains to be done. Some first class examples of how we present our culture, our heritage and our environment are the Stockman's Hall of Fame at Longreach, the Great Barrier Reef Wonderland at Townsville and the new Powerhouse Museum at Darling Harbour. It is this interpretation for the visitors that enables them to enjoy what they are seeing and come away with a far better understanding and appreciation of Australia as a nation. Of course it achieves the same result for Australian visitors as well as those from overseas. It is in this area of interpretation that we are at last recognising how to make Australia understandably exciting and an education to everyone.

That is why I now want to give the Government both a bouquet and a brickbat over this year's Budget. One of the proudest achievements of this Government and one for which I pay tribute, first of all, to Bob Hogg, the Australian Labor Party's National Secretary, and to the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) is the decision in October 1984 to establish the National Film and Sound Archive (NFSA). This is the institution whose responsibility it is to preserve and present to the world Australia's heritage of screen, radio and television. It is a relatively recent heritage, less than a century old, and it is only in recent years that as a nation we have started to realise how important it is to ensure that what we have, we hold.

In a recent article in the Bulletin, I pointed out that 200 years from now Australians will be able to sit back and watch on television the fantastic spectacle on Sydney Harbour on Australia Day. I asked people to imagine what it would be like if we could have watched the arrival of the First Fleet in 1788, an interview with Shakespeare, Drake or Napoleon, the Charge of the Light Brigade, the Battle of Waterloo or Lincoln's Gettysburg Address, or just the life of ordinary people in the sixteenth or seventeenth centuries. I pointed out that this century is unique in that it is the only period in which true moving images and sound can be recorded for future generations. Unfortunately, until 1952, all film had been recorded on cellulose nitrate and after a period it simply disintegrates. The Archive has for years been watching hundreds of thousands of feet of our film heritage finishing up as dust. The budget and the staff of the NFSA were totally inadequate for the job of preserving the 10 million feet of film that the NFSA held in store. As a nation, we were watching our recorded film heritage disintegrate in front of our eyes.

I congratulate the Government, the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories (Senator Richardson) and the Chairman of the Archive, Mr Bob Scott, for having the commonsense to allocate an extra $2.2m for the preservation of this film. It ought to have been done some years ago but, to use the old cliche, `better late than never'. However, this excellent decision will have meaning only if the Archive is assured of continuity of funding. I find it difficult to believe that the Government does not intend to continue funding at approximately the same level for at least the next few years. It would be absurd to fund it for just one year. Equipment will have to be purchased and skilled staff found. Of course, it would be nonsensical to get the program up and running this year and abandon it next year. What is needed is a clear statement from the Minister that it is the intention of the Government to continue the program for a number of years at roughly the same level.

Having said that, let me say how disappointed I am that the Government has not decided to proceed with the upgrading of the National Film and Sound Archive building. The excellent report by the Archive, Time on our Hands, which was presented to me as Minister in March 1985 highlighted the need for a new building to enable the Archive to present our heritage of moving images and recorded sound in an exciting way to the general public. What we have is a very good start, but it is a totally inadequate environment to develop an exciting display. When I was in London in 1986, I visited the Museum of the Moving Image, which at the time was under construction. Just a few nights ago I saw on television a short excerpt about the opening of this fascinating museum. It is obviously impossible to convey the exhilarating visual images of the new museum in a speech of this nature, but let me assure honourable members that it will set a new standard for museums around the world. We would do well to study the British experience.

During the Estimates debate I will continue to point out that I am absolutely appalled by the Government's decision not to proceed with the National Museum of Australia. This is the brickbat that I referred to earlier. I think it is a damn disgrace. That it has occurred in 1988 does no credit to the Government. Time does not permit me to comment any further, but during the Estimates debate I will have a few things to say about the way what would have been, and will be, a great national institution has been pigeonholed for at least five years. I hope that by the time I speak during the Estimates debate this matter will have been reconsidered, because it is a shame and a disgrace that, of all years, it is 1988 in which we are abandoning the National Museum of Australia concept.

TALK.START.PARA: —How much to the black African front line states?

SPEECH.PARA: The point I want to make in the context of this debate is that it is important to remember that old dictum that charity begins at home. SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tickner Mr R.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —The occasion of the passage of the Appropriation Bills through the Parliament provides an opportunity for members of parliament, particularly back bench members of the Government, to rise on issues of concern. Sometimes those issues are of a local nature, sometimes they are of a regional or State nature, and sometimes they are of national significance. Most often they are matters of partisan concern. I propose to raise tonight some issues which I believe transcend party politics and some which, by their very nature, will affect future life on earth.

SPEECH.PARA: As an advanced and relatively prosperous nation, Australia is well placed to play a key role in resolving some of the looming global environmental issues which I will refer to. I believe that to do that we need a bipartisan national commitment. I also believe that parliamentarians have a role to play in stimulating public debate and the support of the community so very necessary to sustain government action. I turn now to the issues.

One of the consequences of the release of chlorofluorocarbon (CFC) inhalants into the atmosphere through industrial usage and through personal usage of a variety of spray cans containing chemicals is that chlorine is released. This acts as a catalyst that speeds up the breakdown of ozone. This results in a lower level of ozone being produced in the upper atmosphere. This is no longer a matter of mere academic interest, because the crunch issue for human civilisation is that that ozone filters out much of the sun's ultraviolet radiation. As a result of that ozone depletion people will be increasingly exposed to higher levels of a potentially dangerous form of radiation. As the United Nations environment program has concluded, increased amounts of damaging ultraviolet radiation (UVB) on the earth's surface causes skin cancer and eye disease, slow plant growth, are lethal to marine algae and break down the chemical structure of paints and plastics.

Currently between 10 and 30 per cent of the sun's UVB reaches the earth's surface. If ozone levels were to fall by 10 per cent, the amount of UVB reaching the earth's surface would increase by about 20 per cent. Worldwide some 100,000 people die every year from skin cancer and UVB is implicated in most cases. It is not an overstatement to say that horrendous implications would result if we allowed the continuing deterioration of the ozone layer.

Fortunately, both in Australia and internationally, action is being taken on the issue. The US banned the use of chlorofluorocarbons in aerosols in 1978; the European Economic Community (EEC) has introduced its own regulations and some countries, such as Belgium and the Nordic countries, have, in effect, banned CFC production altogether. A convention for the protection of the ozone layer was adopted in Vienna in 1985 by 21 states and the EEC at a conference organised by the United Nations environment program. Australia has signed and ratified the convention. The convention further required protocols to be established to reduce the CFC problem and the Montreal Protocol was agreed to in September 1987. Australia has already signed that protocol. Those of us who take an interest in international affairs know how painfully slow it is to get coordinated international action and the fact that the convention and the protocols have been developed so relatively quickly is an indication of the gravity of the issue involved in the depletion of the ozone layer.

The next step is to give effect within Australia to that treaty and I am pleased to note that on 12 July the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories, Senator Richardson, announced that the Government had approved the drafting of legislation to give effect to that protocol. The legislation will place limitations on the supply in Australia of the substances and will also include provisions to ensure that all practical steps are taken to reduce emissions of harmful substances. That involves the use of CFCs in refrigeration and air-conditioning systems, the production of plastic foams in some aerosol sprays and as solvent and degreasing agents in dry-cleaning and the electronics industry, while halons are used for some fire protection purposes.

As Senator Richardson said, Australia truly is at the forefront of international action on this issue and our controls will go well beyond those called for in the Montreal Protocol. I commend the Minister for what he has done. This is an important and prompt initiative and I believe it deserves-and I hope it will receive-the support of the Opposition. But I want to say that we can do even more. Firstly, we should take the initiative internationally to put more stringent restrictions in place than those imposed by the Montreal Protocol. Australia is a country which can be a positive and driving force for good in the world, far beyond our borders and far more significantly than our small population would warrant. We know that in the field of human rights protection and in relation to disarmament Australia has spearheaded some initiatives which have led the world. In the field of environmental protection we can do a lot more and take an equivalent lead. At this point I pay tribute to what the honourable member for Dunkley (Mr Chynoweth) has done. He, perhaps more than any other member, has spoken on this and related issues on many occasions in the Parliament.

TALK.START.PARA: —What about the honourable member for La Trobe on Antarctica?

—Indeed, as the honourable member interjects, there are other honourable members who lead on other issues and I do not wish to detract from them, but I believe the honourable member for Dunkley has made a very important contribution on this issue.

SPEECH.PARA: A further proposal that I wish to make on this issue is to call on the Government to establish an effective monitoring system to measure the ozone levels in Australia. This could be done by setting up a network of Dobson spectrophotometers which would enable those measurements to be made. I believe that the expenditure would be a very worthwhile contribution of taxpayers' funds.

I turn to another global environmental problem which demands a global solution and no one government can deliver that. That issue is, of course, the greenhouse effect. In essence the greenhouse effect is a predicted global warming of the earth expected to result in an increase in the concentration of carbon dioxide and other gases in the atmosphere. This increased level of certain gases allows sunlight to reach the earth's surface, but reduces the amount of infra-red radiation that escapes into space. The greenhouse effect has become more serious with the dramatic increase in the use of fossil fuel as a source of heat energy in the course of this century. This is one of the matters on which we must all reflect a lot more because things are happening so very quickly. Matters that were not even an issue on the political agenda in this country 10 years ago are now looming as critical issues.

Perhaps I could relate a short story within my own experience. I had the opportunity, with the Speaker and a number of my colleagues and members of the Opposition, to participate in a parliamentary delegation to Poland in 1986. While we were in that country we went to Krakow, a very old city which has quite priceless buildings and memories of a bygone age. We found that there had been more damage caused to those buildings in the space of the last 20 years because of acid rain than there had been in the previous 1,000 years. It had been that dramatic. Those are the kinds of changes in the world that we are talking about which demand a coordinated global response.

I return to the greenhouse effect. The accumulation in the atmosphere of those gases of which I spoke acts to trap heat in the lower atmosphere, thus warming the earth. The main gases, in addition to carbon dioxide, include CFCs, methane, nitrous oxide and ozone. Scientists predict that the warming of the global climate in the next 50 years will so change the world's climate that it will cause a rise in the sea level by at least one metre due to thermal expansion of the oceans. It will also change rainfall patterns and result in more intense and widely distributed storms. Mr Barrie Pitlock of the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation (CSIRO) concluded last year that it was highly probable that over the next several decades climatic changes of unprecedented magnitude in human history would take place. The United Nations environment program has estimated that the build-up of gases is likely to increase the temperature of the earth's surface by between 1.5 and 4.5 degrees celsius by the year 2030-hopefully in my lifetime and that of most honourable members here. Clearly that would be sufficient to have a major effect on the earth's climate as even during the last ice age the earth's temperature was only about 5 degrees cooler than it is now. If the changes occur as predicted, in the northern latitudes winters will be shorter and wetter and summers longer and drier. Subtropical regions might become even drier than they are now and tropical regions even wetter. The consequences for human civilisation would be absolutely extraordinary. These changes have an effect on agriculture and natural ecosystems. The United Nations environment program concludes that there is an urgent need for international action to minimise the future greenhouse warming and its social effects.

The Government deserves to be commended for a whole range of environmental decisions taken in the course of its period in office, ranging from the historic decision to stop the flooding of the Franklin River and declaring of 98.5 per cent of the Great Barrier Reef as a marine park to the protection of endangered species and the establishment of a national rainforest program. The list goes on and on. But in relation to the greenhouse effect the record is not good. It is for that reason that I seek, in this debate, to give the Government a prod. It is the role of the back bench member to speak out on issues and to call for government action when it is warranted. That is my purpose here tonight. I am glad that the honourable member for Dunkley, whom I have already praised in the course of my remarks, is here to join me in that call.

The state of play at the moment is this: there is no international coordinated action. In our own country, the Australian Environment Council, consisting of Commonwealth, State and Territory environment Ministers, has recognised climate change due to the greenhouse effect as being a major policy issue and has commenced a review of its potential impact. The Commonwealth Department of the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories is involved in the consideration of the issue at a national level and is contributing to discussions within the international arena. But I remind the Government that the Australian Labor Party national policy calls on the Government, `To urgently implement and maintain research into the greenhouse effect, providing support and incentives for scientific collaboration and study into the effectiveness of alternative policies and adjustments'.

Regrettably, little action has been taken to give effect to this policy. In fact, I am informed that there have been cuts to Australia's major research body, the CSIRO, in this area. I am informed that the CSIRO has recently been refused additional funds for research into the greenhouse effect. I am confident that the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories, Senator Richardson and the Minister for Science, Customs and Small Business (Mr Barry Jones) support increased funding in this area. I call on the Government to give effect to that Party policy.

My time has run out, but let me say this by way of conclusion: the issues that I have raised are just two of the issues of tomorrow. They are the politics of tomorrow. To debate these issues in the national Parliament of Australia in 1988 is an aberration. In 10 years time the front bench of the Opposition and the government of the day will be dealing with these issues as major crisis issues. Let us not wait until then. Let us act now.

The Treasurer (Mr Keating) will collect $47.6 billion in taxation from individuals over the coming 12 months, which is $5.7 billion more than last year. The Treasurer clearly holds the crown as Australia's highest taxing Treasurer. He will add a new notch to that crown during this financial year. Many Australians will pay much more in tax because of bracket creep. The Treasurer will take the extra money for another 12 months and then give only some of it back under the so-called tax cuts, if they occur, in the middle of next year. Under Labor hard work in Australia is rewarded by extraordinarily high taxes.

We had the Treasurer dancing around the international money circuit in Berlin overnight making grand gestures to the effect that he is single-handedly paying off the debt of this nation. He is doing so by degrees-and only by very small degrees-on the backs of Australian taxpayers who, in many cases, are being taxed out of existence. While dealing with this arrogant, out of touch Treasurer who cannot get off the capital city circuit, let me highlight to the House certain matters which are reasonable to raise because they deal with Federal Government expenditure. I do so only in passing, Mr Deputy Speaker. It is a matter of public record that the Treasurer spent nil on charter aircraft last financial year, but $113,045 on official Commonwealth car costs. I do not begrudge him the latter-he has to get around the capital city circuit-but I do begrudge him the first item, the nil expenditure on charter aircraft. I object to that because it reflects the fact that the Treasurer never gets on a charter aircraft to come bush, to come out to the real Australia, to see what the real conditions are in places like Blackall and Longreach, which are still suffering drought after many years. They have not enjoyed the golden revival of the primary industries which is occurring elsewhere in Australia with the better seasonal conditions.

The Treasurer never leaves the capital city circuit-the six major capital cities and the national capital. Sure, one does not run the economy from Bourke or Balranald or Buronga but, by God, it would help a great deal if the Treasurer would observe the situation of inland Australia, if he would take into account in his deliberations or, at the very least, be seen to be making an effort to get away from the capital city circuit to look at what is happening in the real Australia which contributes so much to the well-being and standard of living of all Australians through its export income. So I do very much object to the fact that the Treasurer spent nil dollars on charter aircraft last financial year, and I challenge him, or his office in his absence, to produce one diary entry from the last five years indicating that he has done an extensive day's activity in inland Australia or in places other than capital cities. That would be some edification for honourable members on both sides of the House. The Minister now at the table, the Minister for Land Transport and Shipping Support (Mr Robert Brown), does go up the Hunter Valley and beyond, but that is in sharp contrast to the Treasurer.

I turn to repatriation and veterans' affairs. This is one area in the Budget in which the Government has backed down. The Budget was intact for less than four weeks before the Federal Cabinet had to meet hurriedly one night back here in Canberra to resolve a matter concerning the retrospective aspects of its income assessment package and its impact on age and service pensioners. They had to come scurrying back to Canberra for a special Cabinet meeting, due perhaps not to the rightness of their ultimate decision but to the priority of the Victorian election. Labor is rapidly losing support in the lead-up to the polling day next Saturday. Indeed, messages have been flowing in from people all over Victoria and elsewhere. The campaign by members of the Opposition front bench, including the shadow Minister for Social Security, the honourable member for Bradfield (Mr Connolly), has led to the Government backing down on the retrospective aspects as they pertained to income assessment testing for both age and service pensioners. I know that John Arnold in Mildura and many others have helped influence this outcome by their input to me and others, requesting a fair deal for veterans and a fair deal for our age and service pensioners.

We have a complex situation in that in the Government's backdown, in its abolition of retrospectivity, it has actually created a series of other categories and complex cut-offs which time does not permit me to deal with tonight. The veterans, the age and service pensioners, are still being short changed by the details of the Government's proposals. As we are being broadcast, I suggest that veterans might like to write to my office at Parliament House here in Canberra. I will be happy to send them details in relation to this matter and details of the Liberal-National Party's veterans' affairs policy, which is all about a fair go for veterans. That policy was launched during the winter recess. It lays out a new initiative for an extreme disability adjustment, and did so weeks ahead of the Budget in line with the independent monitoring committee report. I am rather pleased that the extreme disability adjustment was subsequently picked up by this Government and will be the subject of Budget legislation later this year. So our policy was a catalyst at least for that aspect of the Budget. On the broader front, let me say that the Government has yet to come to any decision on the defence service home loans scheme. That scheme ought to be renamed the defence service caravan loans scheme, so greatly has the value of the loans been eroded over recent years. The Government has failed to make any increase.

I must say that the Budget is a very big gamble in respect of the commodity-price equation which the Treasurer presented to this House just a few weeks ago. It is indeed a high risk Budget from an arrogant Government which is out of touch with the people of Australia, in particular the people of inland Australia.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jakobsen Ms C.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is a pleasure to speak on Appropriation Bill (No. 1) and the Budget. It was also a pleasure to hear the contribution of the honourable member for Hughes (Mr Tickner) earlier on a matter of great concern to all Australians and to most people around the world.

SPEECH.PARA: I start by reiterating that Australia is beginning to thrive again. No doubt that comment will not be heralded by the Opposition, but that is because the Opposition is very short-sighted on these matters. The sustained improvement under this Government can be seen in stark contrast to the continuing decline under the previous coalition Government.

The Budget's philosophy, if one can call it that, was to pay off some debt, maintain reform, overcome inflation, and pave the way for affordable tax cuts and sustainable increases in real after-tax incomes. The $5.5 billion surplus follows last year's surplus of $2 billion and is a significant achievement for any government. It is an especially significant achievement for a Labor government which was struggling to overcome the debt problems it inherited from the previous coalition Government.

Why do we need a surplus? We need it to boost business investment, to reduce import pressures, and to cut interest payments. The Treasurer (Mr Keating) has now paid off a substantial amount of the country's national debt. Opposition claims that this surplus was achieved through increased taxes are nonsense and have no foundation. Commonwealth revenues will fall relative to the economy in 1988-89 for the second successive year.

The accord with the unions and the workers of Australia has contributed markedly to the improvement in the economy. It has helped to create more than a million new jobs, 85 per cent of which are in the private sector. Simultaneously, Australia's unemployment rate has dropped to 7 per cent, from 10.3 per cent when Labor came to office in 1983. Inflation is coming down. It was 11.5 per cent in 1983, and our target is 4.5 per cent for 1989. Business investment is rising. Moderate wage increases are in train and further tax cuts will be forthcoming next year. In 1988-89 Australia's balance of payments will be the lowest in nine years, and again that is a significant achievement.

Notwithstanding all the other aspects of the Budget which deserve discussion in this place-and we have heard some discussion about them in the debate to date-employment, training and social security are the areas upon which I would like to concentrate. This Budget contains progressive policies, some of which I shall go through. The `New Start' program is of significant assistance to long term unemployed people between 21 and 54 years of age. It offers a range of assistance and incentives for these people to improve their employability. The Budget allocation of $114m over the next 3 1/2 years will assist in implementing this strategy, which is to be coordinated across departments. Another program, the jobs, education and training program, or JET, is designed to enable sole parent pensioners to become more economically independent by assisting them to enter the work force and lift themselves out of poverty. This is a particularly important initiative, given the difficulties that sole parents face in endeavouring to gain employment.

The third aspect I would like to draw to the House's attention is the return to work allowance, or job entry payment, of $100 to assist with the costs of taking up employment, such as transport and clothing. This may not seem to be incredibly important to people who have a reasonable bank balance, but lack of money for clothes, et cetera, can be a significant disincentive and in fact a barrier to people who have been out of the work force for a long time, if indeed they have ever been in it. In the area of counselling services, provision has been made for 40,000 intensive interviews each year to permit Department of Social Security and Commonwealth Employment Service staff to personally counsel, assess and refer participants to help them obtain the most appropriate training and education and to identify suitable employment opportunities.

This Budget has also made a significant provision for childcare. There is to be an increase of 30,000 places, of which 20,000 will be out of school care places. In regard to training, we will be doubling the places in labour market programs to 50,000. Information processing again may not seem to be an important aspect, but it is most important and there will be a joint Commonwealth Employment Service-Department of Social Security information package. Many people in this House will be aware that the lack of coordination of departmental activities can cause much distress and confusion to any beneficiary seeking assistance.

The cooperation that has been exhibited recently by the departments concerned is admirable and I congratulate the Minister for Employment, Education and Training (Mr Dawkins), the Minister for Social Security (Mr Howe) and the Minister for Employment and Education Services (Mr Duncan) on their part in achieving cohesion in the important areas of service delivery, job training and assistance to unemployed people, other social security beneficiaries seeking employment and also low income working families.

This type of cooperation has been called for by members of the public and members of this Parliament for some time. Indeed, the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Employment, Education and Training, of which I am a member, recently tabled a report called `Getting to Work', which highlighted the barriers confronting social security recipients attempting to enter or re-enter the work force. To the Government's great credit, many of its recommendations have been taken up in the Budget, even though the Government's official response has not yet been received.

For instance, recommendation No. 1 of the report concerns an easing of the work test to include other relevant job search activities, such as part time and casual employment, training and education-an elementary recommendation, one would have thought, but one which has been a long time coming from all governments concerned in the process of trying to assist long term unemployed. This recommendation is taken up in the proposed `New Start' program, which is designed to assist long term unemployed people to improve their employability. It permits a wider range of vocationally relevant activity, such as short term courses, while on unemployment benefit and also the waiver of waiting periods when reclaiming benefits in certain circumstances.

Recommendations 7 and 8 of `Getting to Work' highlight the need to increase access to counselling and indicate that the Department of Social Security counselling and reporting responsibilities should be expanded to include advice to social security recipients about suitable education, training and employment programs before recipients lose entitlement to pension or benefit. This is a matter which I know the honourable member for Moncrieff (Mrs Sullivan) has taken up at some length, and she is to be given credit for putting that in the report. Again, as part of the `New Start' program, 40,000 intensive interviews, as I mentioned earlier, will now be undertaken each year and the staff of the Department of Social Security and the Commonwealth Employment Service will provide personal counselling, assessment and referral for participants.

Recommendation No. 17 of the report says that preparatory courses on the model of the `New opportunities for women' course should be developed as an introduction to training or employment. These are module courses which can precede any other training. `New Start' incorporates a doubling of places on labour market programs to 50,000, including a range of preparatory and vocational training opportunities, subsidised work experience and job search assistance to suit the needs of individual job seekers. I know that the Government views very seriously the need for a short course to introduce people to training where those people have not had training before.

Recommendation No. 17 emphasises the need to provide a return to work allowance, paid as an advance, for social security recipients who have been out of the workplace for a long time. This also has been included in the Budget. The sum of $100 is a very necessary part of the Government's undertaking. Again, it may not seem much; but, as I have indicated, it is very important for people who have no money at all in the bank and who confront a financial barrier when seeking work and wish to be appropriately dressed, or at least to be able to get there on time by catching transport, or perhaps even by hiring a car on the first occasion.

The social security review describes the prerequisites of a system to help people find work in the following way. The first prerequisite is that clear information be provided as to what is expected of the participants or beneficiaries. The second is that there be encouragement as well as penalty. The third looks to the provision of the necessary training resources and continuing information being made available. The fourth prerequisite is that the requirements are generally regarded as reasonable and achievable. Although administrative arrangements in the relevant departments have not always satisfied these criteria, measures contained in the Budget should go a long way towards improving that situation.

To conclude, I remind the House that the Budget we are debating is one which carries a lot of good news-that is, that the economy is on the way back to prosperity, with inflation falling, real wage increases in the wings, business investment strong, rates of job growth robust and tax cuts for workers proposed from 1 July 1989. Specific items that are worth reiterating include `New Start' for jobless people; jobs, education and training for sole parents; 30,000 extra child care places; increases in Austudy and Abstudy; increases in family allowance supplement payments; and additional assistance for disabled veterans. The achievements in this Budget were made possible only by the continued success of the Government's economic strategy. That has been no small feat and was possible only because of the unity of purpose of our Party in government. I congratulate the Treasurer and commend the Bill to the House.
